Short Summary

Hi, I'm Ebru Eltemur, a curator and visual artist based in New York. Currently studying at NYU Gallatin School of Individualized Study, my interests lie in understanding the politics of art institutions, and curating exhibitions in post-colonial cultural spaces, from museums to public art spaces. My work has been featured at the Gallatin Arts Festival (2017) and “Friends of 8Ball Community” show at Entrance Gallery (2018), and published in independent zines and art review magazines. While I have gained some experience by co-curating, “Slicing Burning Boiling” will be my solo curatorial debut.

Slicing Burning Boiling is an experimental response to the often exclusive and discriminatory nature of the contemporary art market. Featuring young artists who critically interface with capitalist, Euro-centric education systems, the exhibition disrupts the impulse to create commercialized art by exhibiting highly personal, intimate work. Further, it disputes the abusive correlation between value and labor in art-making. In doing so, it renegotiates the “process” of becoming a successful “artist” and questions the authority of those who have established such boundaries for decades.

 

Slicing Burning Boiling analyzes the difficult process of identity-making in a commodified art world, and finding solace in what makes us vulnerable and unique. It is an amalgam of undisclosed thoughts, abused emotions and lessened ambitions.
<h3>What We Need &amp
I need about 5,500 dollars to fund the rent and decoration of the space and exhibition publications, including an opening reception invitation and catalogue.
The perks you can get are listed on the sidebar!
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are not able to financially support the project, please spread the word around and invite your friends to see the show. Even the smallest contribution counts!

<h3>When You Can't Tell The Difference Between Political Rhetoric &amp

That's the goal here. Let's take the left's own rhetoric and dress it up like a kid's book and watch them rage cry if they get the joke or embrace it if they think it's real. This book is not intended to be used for literal children, it is to expose grown ups acting like children.
Any money raised off this campaign will essentially go to funding my YouTube channel since every video I make there is demonitized.

Dark-Hunter Collectible Pins Are Here!
Sherrilyn McQueen has teamed up with Skyland Arts to create a series of stylized character pins, now available for pre-order.
<ul>
• Hard enamel / cloisonné pins that will last and wear well.
• Metal butterfly clasp back.
• Black plated nickel
• Special Black Signature Edition! Available with this casting only, Sherri's signature will be featured on every pin.
Pins are already in production
Skyland Arts is up and running with this limited Signature Edition casting of pins. This Indiegogo campaign will help to determine how many of each pin to cast and create.
Ultra-limited Signature Edition!

After this run, future pins featuring these Dark-Hunter characters will not include the Sherrilyn McQueen signature - so this run is super limited! Fans who procrastinate will miss out on this signature version. They'll be asking you a year from now at whatever con is open ""Hey! How the hell did you get an Acheron pin with Sherri's signature on it?!""
UPDATE! Production line pics are here!

We're excited to share photos from the manufacturing process that just came in. These are in progress and show that there's still work being done to clean up and polish the pins. They'll be shipping soon!
Who is Skyland Arts?

Skyland Arts has been around since 2019. Their background is tabletop gaming (White Wolf Publishing), videogames (Meteor Entertainment, Secret Weapon Animation), comics and graphic novels (BOOM! Studios, Magnetic Press) and manga &
<ul>
• Follow us on IG @skylandarts and FB for more news and spoilers.
• PLEASE help us get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
• And remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to help us along.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

With over two decades working within the pop culture community in product development and logistics, Skyland Arts has a lot of experience with art and product production, project management of products like these. We work with our external partners and factories on a daily basis to make sure things stay on track. That said, there can be unavoidable delays with these types of projects, especially with shipping from overseas and dealing with customs. We have tried our best to allow enough time with our expected ship date to account for these potential delays. However, we do not foresee this being an issue at the moment. Our partners rock! There may be some changes made to designs during the production process. This is a normal part of product development and will not make these pins any less awesome! We will keep all of our backers updated throughout the production process, so you will know if anything unexpected has come up and what we are doing to resolve it quickly.

Background

Log Book is a project based on my father's World War Two pilot's log book. He was an RAF Lancaster pilot flying for the Pathfinder Force between April 1943 and January 1944, completing 48 missions to 25 different towns and cities over Germany and northern Italy. Below is a photograph of the actual log book, which was in fact issued by the Royal Canadian Air Force. I believe this was simply what was available and given to him at the time.

The project

I will visit all 25 towns and cities listed in this log book. I photograph at night, as the RAF flew at night, as close to the actual calendar date of each mission as possible, in many cases on exactly the same date. The images shown here were all made on the same date as in the log book.

                               Krefeld, 21stJune .

The images are of the streets, canals, harbours and buildings of the various places I visit. The locations are loosely based on research of documents from the time which I have found at the National Archive in London. But I do not seek to represent any specific locations, rather to allow the images to stimulate reflection on what took place on those nights.

                               Hamburg, 27th July .

Log Book 2019

I began in June 2017 and plan to complete photography in January 2019, 75 years after the actual dates. In the spring/summer of 2019 I then plan to publish my own photographic version of the original in a very similar design and format, simply entitled ""Log Book"". My intention is to include in this a number of images from the National Archive in London. These are photographs taken from the air on the dates and over the cities in question. For licensing reasons I am not able to show these at this stage.

                               Mühlheim, 22nd June.

Progress

Last year I travelled to Münster, Krefeld, Mühlheim-an-der-Ruhr, Hamburg, Hannover and Leipzig. This year I have already been to Duisburg, Bochum, Dortmund, Wuppertal and Cologne. In August I will fly to northern Italy and photograph in La Spezia, Genoa, Turin, Milan and Modane over the border in southern France. The remaining cities in Germany are Nuremberg, Munich, Stuttgart, Mannheim, Frankfurt-am-Main, Kassel, Berlin and finally Szczecin Poland, formerly the German city of Stettin.

Funding

The purpose of this campaign is to help fund the travel and production costs involved in realising the photographic part of this project. This will enable me to complete the photography in January 2019 as planned. Otherwise I will have to continue until later in the year, potentially even into 2020.

I am making three images available in sizes and at prices unique to this promotion.  The other images from the series will only be available next year in very small editions in exhibition sizes.

My books are also available at special prices on my website (www.mikechick.com) during this promotion.

If you would like to contribute, you can do so by donating an amount or choosing one of the perks. Please have a look, and if you have any questions please do drop me a line. Many thanks.

Finally, special thanks to Nadja Tobias (www.nadjatobias.com) for her help with the making of the film shown here.

Short Summary

My name is Suritah Teresa Kaluzova Wignall and my absolute passion is creating, I don't want to do anything else. I feel that I was born to paint, to discover as much as I can about art. At times it is a struggle, I have been doing this for over 20 years and I have been learning to make a profession from it for the past 10 years. I have had many successes and experienced many failures. But through the joys, hurt, the pain, the struggle, it comes down to me not giving up and I refuse to. I don't want to be famous, I just want to continue to do what I love to do. And see how much of my full self I can experience.

My current project is entitled, The Waking Dream, it recently exhibited in the South of Spain over the summer and it was a huge success. I have been invited to have another show in Seville and Madrid, but I am continuing with the creation  process.
My
work takes a look at social and cultural issues. I often like to
deconstruct the societal idea of what is considered beautiful, the
fairy tale, the lie, that tells us a specific woman is more beautiful
than the other. Especially having seen and being told my whole life
that dark is not beautiful, my subject is usually women, black women
in different themes and settings. My medium is usually paint and
mixed media
I like to  use a variety of materials and processes in each project,
my methodology is consistent. Although there may not always be
material similarities between the different projects they are linked
by recurring formal concerns and through the subject matter.
This
time around I wanted to do something a little bit different. I can
not change who it is that I am, I am learning how to accept things for
exactly what they are and through that my art has changed, I created
a series of watercolor works. Inspired by Philip Glass and his minimalism in music, <span style=""line-height: 1.45em
wanted the images to be minimal
use of color and mixed media, so that the audience can focus in on
the subject and get lost in the story. This is my story of learning to just accept who it is I am and conquer fear.
column7:
What You Get

What I need is another $3000 for the continuation of this project, what you'll be helping with my plan to work on 8 more images because it is a series, purchasing art supplies, doing more research, I love the Toronto reference Library and I tend to spend a lot of time there researching ideas and images for upcoming or continued projects. You will also be helping me to stay in my studio so that I can work.

WHAT YOU RECEIVE:

well, lets make this fun, not only will you receive some amazing art by me, orginal and prints. But I am also offering a night of painting
column8:
a painting workshop for you and 2 of your friends, A color theory workshop. If you are an artist yourself, an grant writing workshop for you and 2 of your friends, because I am a grant writing and networking machine. I am happy to share my skills with you. And if you are supporting from out of Canada, then original and print art is what I will offer to you. As well as portraits for you or a loved one

If full funds are not received, then whatever is mustered up will allow me to still do research and create new images.
column19: >I already had an exhibit in the South of Spain which was extremely nerve racking and exciting for me. I never thought that my art would make it this far. But it did. And its only going to get better. It is extremely hard to make a career as an artist, the one thing that I can tell you is that I am dedicated, extremely hard working and refuse to give up. If you support me, you will be supporting someone who will see a project through to the end. You can check my track record. I am always up to something exciting and new
column20: if its not collaborating with Erykah Badu or working with the community, then I am studying music in Spain, having a solo exhibit in Seville and planning future solo exhibits in Madrid. My first solo exhibit was at A Space Gallery in Toronto, I have designed dressing rooms for major recording artists, album covers and book covers, received grants and won awards and believe that my future is bright.
column26:
>It is true, that grants dont always come through and I am always looking for ways to support my art. If its not taking on commissions, working part time, taking on contracts or if I am very lucky selling my work. But I always seem to find a way. If you cant help with small funds that is ok, but maybe you can help by spreading the word, to people you may know that may either be interested in supporting or interested in purchasing some original works of art or prints. I dont always like to rely on the system I do believe that as a community an arts community, we should and can support eachother. Thank You!

Hi im James Steele

In March im off to Kenya, Africa to help build an orphanage called Umoja. The Orphanage is still in its early stages, and i want to capture the journey and the stories of the people who are making it a reality. 

While at Umoja the team and I will be:
• Planting Fruit Trees
•  erecting green houses
•  building an animal shelter and a chicken coop
•  visiting mentor orphanages in the area
• meeting with the children and cooking for the orphans.

the orphanage is located in Laiki beach southwest of Mombasa 

My intention is to document the real life human stories and the people who make Umoja happen through photography and video elements.

In march 2013 I collaborated with a local artist to host my first successful photography exhibition , Natural Amity

When I return I will host my second exhibition Umoja Genesis.

- Some of my work will also appear on umojahome.com the orphanages webpage, along with prints and a DVD of my photos and video interviews.

 Here is a link to the Umoja Home page 

With the help of my friends and family, and a lot of fundraisers and donations from wonderful people, I have already raised over $3000 to fund my project

In order to cover the costs of the trip and ensure i can take all my photography equipment to the area i need to raise another $2200


","Hi im James SteeleIn March im off to Kenya, Africa to help build an orphanage called Umoja. The Orphanage is still in its early stages, and i want to capture the journey and the stories of the people who are making it a reality. While at Umoja the team and I will be:
Planting Fruit Trees
erecting green houses
building an animal shelter and a chicken coop
visiting mentor orphanages in the area
meeting with the children and cooking for the orphans.

column1:
If the 310,786 GBP goal is not met, aren’t there Indiegogo penalties?

Yes, a 9% service fee will apply. If the goal is met, the service fee is reduced to 4%. PayPal processing fees are around 3%. 

Can credit cards be used for payment? 

Unfortunately not. Since I don't have a UK bank account and need to run this campaign in GBP, PayPal is the only licit way to accept donations :/ 

What if Lot 128  fails to sell at auction?

All money raised as Lot 128 (minus Indiegogo fees) will go to the most-voted-for-charity.

","Hi,This is Darren Bader. I hope you’d be interested in helping me realize this artwork: About the artwork
The artwork is the amount of money raised here by February 11, 2015.
The artwork will be up for auction on February 12, 2015 at the Christie's Post-War and Contemporary Day Sale in London.
Will the winning bid be more than, less than, or equal to the amount of money raised here? (Will there be a bid at all?)
The amount of the winning bid will go to charity.
The artwork will be attributed to Darren Bader.

Donor anonymity is an option of course.What would the winning bidder do with the artwork?It would be his/her prerogative to do whatever s/he wants with it. The work is [tbd] GBP.
The work can be kept/taken/destroyed/used/found/forgotten however the owner chooses.
The work will remain [tbd] GBP irrespective of market fluctuations.
What do you hope to achieve by this, Darren Bader?
I want to continue my interest in defining sculpture as any known quantity (however novel) resident to any perceived space (however novel).
A further elucidation of what may (not) define the art market.
TBD as the process moves along (hopefully a positive education).

column4: >This coffee table book will document all my efforts to raise global awareness about the key issues I believe are of high importance, like
column7: >social-, animal rights, and environmental causes .
column10:
>
 Most of the time some of these issues are not sufficiently highlighted on mainstream media.

column5:
/>

My book will document the 2 years of ""Artivism""-actions I created regarding all sorts of social-, and animal rights, and environmental issues. Below each high-quality image, I will explain what inspired me to do the Art-protests, as well as the information you need to know about the issues I bring to light.
To make this book a reality I need to raise $5,000 within a month in order to be able to cover part of the costs for the first run. Each copy of my coffee-table book costs $45 to print, which does not include shipping costs. A major part of the profits will be used to take my artivism to the next level and keep growing while spreading more awareness about issues that we all need to improve.

column1: By buying a signed limited-printing copy in advance, you will contribute to making this happen and help to spread the Love Revolution worldwide so others can learn from example and be inspired by it.

Once I print the first run of the book, I plan to sell copies on Amazon and Ebay and start travelling around doing book presentations, so I can raise more funds and keep printing more copies in the future.

Below each image, I will explain every cause I artistically fight for and inform people about the dangers that are being dismissed because of public ignorance. It's a way to teach humanity about what can be improved once we have acknowledged that it exists.
column3:
/>

Jil LOVE REVOLUTION is a International Social Movement which creates ARTivism, Art + Activism to raise awareness, motivate society, and expand consciousness.
My mission is to awaken a force in those who view our images...To raise awareness, ignite ideas, and incite people into action. We peacefully and artistically fight for Social Rights, Animal rights and Environmental issues. We are the voices of the unheard. We are the images of the unseen.
I believe this book will inspire others to create their own Love Revolution and together help make a the world a better place to live in.

column1: The first ARTIVISM protest began during the Spanish Riots on September 25th and 29th, 2012. Any Love-Revolution starts by loving yourself. Only then can you truly love others.

Hi Everyone, 

This is Sherida Holland. We're starting our second campaign for Mountain Cabin Studio. We want to thank everyone who contributed and promoted our first campaign last year! View our first campaign. We were able to reach our goal and get the work so desperately needed done on the cabin in Melrose Montana. It's a giant step in the right direction and we no longer fear the cabin will fall in or have to be torn down. The cabin has a new foundation and the north wall is no longer structurally unsound. Marty Salusso and Mark Salusso with Centennial Concrete in Butte Montana did all the work.

New to this campaign, the opportunity for everyone to participate  with the introduction of a referral contest!!!  For information and details, please refer to our updates. A prize will be given every week based on the cumulative analytics of referrals and resulting donations. The grand prize will be a week at the cabin and a week at the cabin donated in your name to a person or group for physical, mental, emotional or spiritual healing!!!

The cabin had to be moved back from it's original location, with the sun porch moved forward. The old rocks it had been sitting on were moved away. The site was excavated so we could pour our footings 32"" below ground. Then the foundation was poured using Insulated Concrete Forms, or ICF. In the process we were able to put in a new floor and a new course of logs under the cabin all around the bottom, replacing the old ones that were rotten. This was all thanks to the kindness and generosity of our wonderful supporters and contributors. You are always more than welcome to stay at the cabin and enjoy all that Montana has to offer!!

 BEFORE:
column11:
schema=youtube"" width=""580""> AFTER:

Mountain Cabin Studio II

Picking up where the last campaign left off, the second goal is to complete the restoration of the cabin, estimated at $24,900. We've divided this into two equal parts, in order to insure completion of the more critical aspects of the restoration.  First and foremost, we will re-build the roof per the original design. We will use 4""-5"" logs for the rafters and old rough cut lumber (old barn wood) for the decking. The new rafters will be 16"" on center instead of 24"", like they were. This will also include a new ridge pole, and new logs for the top plates. Leaving the ceiling open for a cathedral ceiling, we will place new king post tie beams at every third rafter, 2' above the wall height. Kay Jensen of Divide Montana harvested and hand peeled the logs last summer so they could dry and be cured for use this summer. Instead of the old rolled roofing, we are going to add rigid foam insulation and sheet metal roofing, on the cabin and the porch. This will be approximately half, or $12,450 of the second goal, set out in the original campaign dedicated to the completion of the restoration of the cabin.

Just as important, but dependent on the second $12,450, we can wash, bleach, and oil the logs, and put in new chinking. We will reclaim and restore the old windows and doors, re-gluing, filling and oiling the wooden frames and re-glazing where necessary. We will frame in a new door on the north side and reattach and stabilize the porch on the west side. Then all the windows and doors will be reset, insulated, trimmed and painted. The electrical will be rerun providing outlets and lighting. Voila! The cabin is like new.

Third and Final Goal: Additions and Modernization

With the hard work behind us, the additions of a wrap around porch (inclusive of the current porch being made into a sun room), bedroom and bathroom will be straight forward, including a small kitchen in the cabin. We already have a well and sewer access on the property so it's just a matter of running pipes and getting a pump and pressure tank for the well. Back-fill, grading and some landscaping will finish the job. When completed, this our final goal, to be launched in a separate campaign, will enable us to have guests at the cabin or offer it for retreats and workshops, since even though restored, the cabin is still a one room cabin with an outhouse.

My hope is that Mountain Cabin Studio, set in the rugged wilderness, vast openness and breathtaking beauty of Montana, can take us beyond human impermanence with it’s compulsive posturing, grasping, withholding and obsessing. To bring people to the awareness of beauty and grandeur I first experienced in the wilderness as a child. To foster peace, fortitude and a sense of belonging. To promote physical, mental, emotional and spiritual healing. To offer a sanctuary to those who want to reconnect and rekindle their spirit. Quoting John Muir, ""Wilderness takes you beyond your human existence to become one with nature and the universe.""

To complement and reinforce this sense of grace and equanimity,  workshops or sabbaticals can be organized, sponsored and attended by any group, cause or association. Along with the perks offered here and on the first campaign of my art

column1: and art books (pictured below), you can book a week at the cabin. Because of your help
to save the cabin, we want to help others in your name. For
every week booked by you we will donate a week retreat at the cabin for a
workshop or sabbatical that supports artists and writers, or supports

physical, mental, emotional or spiritual healing, such as:

Aging and Evolving Retreat:

Artists' and Writers' Retreat: paint, write, be inspired

Bereavement Retreat: loss of a loved one to cancer, suicide, or traumatic event

Bipolar and Mental Challenges Retreat: depression and anxiety, social disorders, addictions

Cancer Survivors Retreat: celebrate life and overcome the trauma of an ongoing life threatening disease

Caregivers Retreat:
column5:
/>

Church Groups Retreat:

Earth Angels and Healers:

Nature Retreat: explore sacred wilderness,

Outdoors Man Retreat: rugged outdoor activities

Urbanization Isolation Retreat: social isolation, fear, anxiety, lack of community

Veterans Retreat: post traumatic stress disorder, re-entering society

Yoga and Mindfulness Retreat: holistic fitness, wellness and mindful living

Youth Groups Retreat:
column23:
We had three people book a week at the cabin last campaign, Debbie Miyake, Dave Harris and Carrie Mayhew. Thank you sooo much!!! Posted in the updates is a recap of the three recipients awarded a week at the cabin in their name!!!

                                                    <
column37:
Pictured below are the perks from the first campaign of beautiful,  fine art prints, on 100% cotton rag paper, signed and numbered, of watercolors painted around Butte and Melrose. They are available framed or unframed ( see gallery). Choose a print from this series of Montana wildflowers, painted above Melrose. Or choose the painting below titled ""Mountain Cabin,"" painted above Butte (30 miles north of Melrose) facing the Pintlar Mountains.

          Blazing Star                         Alpine Bluebell                   Indian Paintbrush

                                                             Mountain Cabin 

Introduced late in the last campaign:          Click on the title to view the art book:

this watercolor of Stargazer Lilies            I Love to Wander Down Mountain Roads

As an artist I challenge the people of Queens, NYC - and beyond - to help me defy the stereotype of the cut-throat, egotistical, self-centered New Yorker by doing FAVORS for friends, family and strangers in April, 2013.
But you do not have to be in Queens to do FAVORS! Anyone, anywhere can do a favor and get on the Map of FAVORS in April.

I’ll be working with at least SEVEN different community and arts organizations and anyone else who would like to be part of the project. So far our community partners are LaGuardia Performing Arts Center, Long Island City Artists, Jackson Heights Green Alliance,  Sunnyside Community Services, and Flushing High School, Rockaways Waterfront Alliance and the Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning.
All these groups do great work in their communities and we’re really looking forward to doing FAVORS with them. We are open to working with more partner organizations in Queens, if you know of any!
But even if you’re not affiliated with these organizations, you can still participate in FAVORS! This is a work of art that we are all creating together.
Why FAVORS Needs Your Help and What You'll Get
I’m happy to say that we’ve been funded in part by the Queens Council on the Arts (thank you QCA!). But our project budget is $7,100 and I still need $4,850.
We need funds for advertising, for outreach, for publicity, for printing, for insurance, for a videographer, a photographer, and more.  It’s a lot of stuff.
The good news is you can do favors for FAVORS by donating to the project right here through Indiegogo. Your contribution to the project is tax deductible through my fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas.
And even though you may be doing this out of complete generosity, like a true favor,  we will give you something in return. Please see the perk list to the right for the FAVORS stuff you can get.
You're Invited to Participate in FAVORS!

Even if you aren’t able to help FAVORS financially at this time, you can still do us a favor by spreading the word about FAVORS or by coming to Queens and doing someone a favor! Or if you can't make to Queens, do someone a favor wherever you are and let us know about it.
This is a work of art that we are all creating together.

If you can’t make it to Queens you can still be part of FAVORS. In April just let us about your favor: https://www.facebook.com/FAVORS or email: doingFAVORS@gmail.com or twitter: @doingFAVORS . And if none of those work for you send me a postcard at: Priscilla Studio, 44-02 23rd St, Long Island City, NY 11101.
What Kind of FAVOR Do You Mean?

If you’re not sure what kind of favor to do, you can check out our website: http://favorscommunity.wordpress.com where there will be a list of FAVORS offered by people who want to do them. Or you can offer to do someone else a favor there.

FAVORS should take less than three hours including transportation time. It should not involve money or any type of coercion, and it has to be legal, of course! Also please keep in mind there will be kids involved in the project.

Once you let us know about the favor(s) you did, we’ll add it to the Map of FAVORS on google, which will show where all of our FAVORS are being done. Which brings me to Part 2 of FAVORS: the installation.
The Map of FAVORS Installation

The installation is an interactive sculpture that you can walk through and read. It will be made from hanging paper spirals, each with a favor someone did written on it. It will be based on the Map of FAVORS!

At the installation we’ll also have events, including a theater piece created by LaGuardia Performing Arts Center, one of our community partners. And we’ll have an artists’ talk and a group discussion with FAVORS participants and a panel to discuss issues related to doing FAVORS.

For example, when do you decide not to do a favor? Or is your culture or cultures that you’re familiar with actually based on doing favors? Or have you ever been politically pressured to do favors? Whatever topics come up in the process of doing FAVORS we will have space to discuss them in events at the installation.
So Are We Ready to do FAVORS in April?
Yes! Here are just a few of the FAVORS people are planning to do.
Michael is going to babysit for his friend’s baby!
Sada is going to buy some clothes for her brother’s family and send it to them in her country, Bangladesh!
Marcus is going to give his friend singing lessons!
By Supporting FAVORS...
You’ll help create massive goodwill!
You’ll help disprove the myth of the cut-throat, egotistical, self-centered New Yorker!
You’ll get a tax deduction for your charitable donation!
You’ll get cool FAVORS stuff!
You’ll help people explore what FAVORFS mean in different cultural, political and emotional contexts!
You’ll receive our genuine, heartfelt gratitude!
You’ll be doing FAVORS a favor!
And most of all you’ll help make FAVORS happen in Queens – and anywhere anyone does someone a favor!
Cassy’s Words of Wisdom

Listen to Cassy. She says doing favors for people should make you feel good, and you should not expect monetary return or any type of material benefit from it. Cassy thinks FAVORS is a great idea, and she wants to see what’s going to happen with the project!
So do we, and we hope you do, too. We hope you'll both support the project and join us in doing FAVORS!
<div>
The Impact
The point of FAVORS is to help people connect with each other in different ways than they normally might.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
<ul>
• Please spread the word about FAVORS! That would be a tremendous favor!
• You can use the Indiegogo share tools to let people know about FAVORS!
• And in April you are invited to join us in this massive art project by doing a favor - in Queens, NYC or wherever you can - and telling us about it so we can add you to the Map of FAVORS!
FAVORS supported in part by the Queens Council on the Arts!

This  project is made possible in part by the Queens Council on the Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council. I greatly appreciate their support and encourage you to join QCA and the NY City Council in supporting FAVORS!

","As an artist I challenge the people of Queens, NYC - and beyond - to help me defy the stereotype of the cut-throat, egotistical, self-centered New Yorker by doing FAVORS for friends, family and strangers in April, 2013.
But you do not have to be in Queens to do FAVORS! Anyone, anywhere can do a favor and get on the Map of FAVORS in April.

I’ll be working with at least SEVEN different community and arts organizations and anyone else who would like to be part of the project. So far our community partners are LaGuardia Performing Arts Center, Long Island City Artists, Jackson Heights Green Alliance,  Sunnyside Community Services, and Flushing High School, Rockaways Waterfront Alliance and the Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning.
All these groups do great work in their communities and we’re really looking forward to doing FAVORS with them. We are open to working with more partner organizations in Queens, if you know of any!
But even if you’re not affiliated with these organizations, you can still participate in FAVORS! This is a work of art that we are all creating together.
Why FAVORS Needs Your Help and What You'll Get
I’m happy to say that we’ve been funded in part by the Queens Council on the Arts (thank you QCA!). But our project budget is $7,100 and I still need $4,850.
We need funds for advertising, for outreach, for publicity, for printing, for insurance, for a videographer, a photographer, and more.  It’s a lot of stuff.
The good news is you can do favors for FAVORS by donating to the project right here through Indiegogo. Your contribution to the project is tax deductible through my fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas.
And even though you may be doing this out of complete generosity, like a true favor,  we will give you something in return. Please see the perk list to the right for the FAVORS stuff you can get.
You're Invited to Participate in FAVORS!

Even if you aren’t able to help FAVORS financially at this time, you can still do us a favor by spreading the word about FAVORS or by coming to Queens and doing someone a favor! Or if you can't make to Queens, do someone a favor wherever you are and let us know about it.
This is a work of art that we are all creating together.

If you can’t make it to Queens you can still be part of FAVORS. In April just let us about your favor: https://www.facebook.com/FAVORS or email: doingFAVORS@gmail.com or twitter: @doingFAVORS . And if none of those work for you send me a postcard at: Priscilla Studio, 44-02 23rd St, Long Island City, NY 11101.
What Kind of FAVOR Do You Mean?

If you’re not sure what kind of favor to do, you can check out our website: http://favorscommunity.wordpress.com where there will be a list of FAVORS offered by people who want to do them. Or you can offer to do someone else a favor there.

FAVORS should take less than three hours including transportation time. It should not involve money or any type of coercion, and it has to be legal, of course! Also please keep in mind there will be kids involved in the project.

Once you let us know about the favor(s) you did, we’ll add it to the Map of FAVORS on google, which will show where all of our FAVORS are being done. Which brings me to Part 2 of FAVORS: the installation.
The Map of FAVORS Installation

The installation is an interactive sculpture that you can walk through and read. It will be made from hanging paper spirals, each with a favor someone did written on it. It will be based on the Map of FAVORS!

At the installation we’ll also have events, including a theater piece created by LaGuardia Performing Arts Center, one of our community partners. And we’ll have an artists’ talk and a group discussion with FAVORS participants and a panel to discuss issues related to doing FAVORS.

For example, when do you decide not to do a favor? Or is your culture or cultures that you’re familiar with actually based on doing favors? Or have you ever been politically pressured to do favors? Whatever topics come up in the process of doing FAVORS we will have space to discuss them in events at the installation.
So Are We Ready to do FAVORS in April?
Yes! Here are just a few of the FAVORS people are planning to do.
Michael is going to babysit for his friend’s baby!
Sada is going to buy some clothes for her brother’s family and send it to them in her country, Bangladesh!
Marcus is going to give his friend singing lessons!
By Supporting FAVORS...
You’ll help create massive goodwill!
You’ll help disprove the myth of the cut-throat, egotistical, self-centered New Yorker!
You’ll get a tax deduction for your charitable donation!
You’ll get cool FAVORS stuff!
You’ll help people explore what FAVORFS mean in different cultural, political and emotional contexts!
You’ll receive our genuine, heartfelt gratitude!
You’ll be doing FAVORS a favor!
And most of all you’ll help make FAVORS happen in Queens – and anywhere anyone does someone a favor!

column6: >Casa Mea is a non-profit, 501c3 public charity which provides loving group homes for orphaned and abandoned children in developing countries from birth through adulthood. Currently, Casa Mea has two homes, one in Romania and one just starting in Guatemala. Some of our Romanian children came from the streets or were abandoned at a restaurant or public park as infants. The children we care for often have many emotional as well as physical issues which are eased with an abundance of love, art, and music.

<div style=""line-height: 21px
column2: >This year the children in Romania designed Christmas cards that we will have printed with the funds provided by this campaign. We will sell thhe cards to local (US) churches, groups, and individuals in hope that we can do it again next year with the funds we raise this year. The effort helps to build confidence and a sense of ownership and pride in what the children have done. Your donation brings much happiness to these children who have gone through more in their short lives than any little person should ever go through. These kids are super excited about contributing their talents to this project.

","About us:

Casa Mea is a non-profit, 501c3 public charity which provides loving group homes for orphaned and abandoned children in developing countries from birth through adulthood. Currently, Casa Mea has two homes, one in Romania and one just starting in Guatemala. Some of our Romanian children came from the streets or were abandoned at a restaurant or public park as infants. The children we care for often have many emotional as well as physical issues which are eased with an abundance of love, art, and music.

This year the children in Romania designed Christmas cards that we will have printed with the funds provided by this campaign. We will sell thhe cards to local (US) churches, groups, and individuals in hope that we can do it again next year with the funds we raise this year. The effort helps to build confidence and a sense of ownership and pride in what the children have done. Your donation brings much happiness to these children who have gone through more in their short lives than any little person should ever go through. These kids are super excited about contributing their talents to this project.
We can guarantee the following:
100% of your donation will benefit Casa Mea's Christmas card project.
100% of your donation is tax deductible.
100% of your donation will bring pride and happiness to our children.

With your support and encouragement, these children will know that others care and are engaged in their future.  Thanks for considering a donation!Thanks to The Mound - Westonka Rotary Club of Minnesota for already donating $300. We challenge other Rotary Clubs to join in!

Hi!
I am Kelsey Maloney.  I grew up
among the lakes, meadows, and forests of South Lake Tahoe, California.  I
am 5’9 ½” tall.  I am a daughter, a sister, an aunt.  I am playful,
sincere, contemplative.  I dance.  I write.  I adventure.
I love birds, moss, and ice-cream.  I love big thunderstorms, cold water
swimming, and letters in the mail.  I
don’t love ham, ticking clocks, or shopping malls.  I do love Australia.
Australia!
In February 2014, I am going to Australia for 9 to 12 months.  I am
fundraising for a 5-month portion of my trip:
an artistic journey into the Northern reaches of the country.
Why am I

going to northern Australia?   To study and draw birds and write stories about birds (and many other creatures too)!  They are heartmonster stories. We all have a heartmonster.  He lives inside our chests and attends to our truest of hearts.  He is a best friend, a protector, a truth keeper.  My hope is to take the drawings and stories I write in Australia, along with other pieces already written, and make a children’s storybook for all ages.   Please check out the pictures in the ""gallery"" to see heartmonster drawings and a sampling of bird life in Australia.

Why am I going to northern Australia?  Because I love it there and it
feels like home.  When I traveled to Australia in 2009 for one year, I
spent several months in Western Australia.  On a road trip up north with a
dear friend, we stopped at a national park in the Pilbarra region for several
days.  The land was rich with pokey grasses, massive gorges, red rocks,
and a scattering of gum trees.  At this place, on this land, I felt all
through my body ‘I AM HOME.  I’VE COME HOME.’  I’d never experienced
something like that in regards to a place before.  So clear and embodied.
I am
raising money so I can have my basic needs covered, allowing me to focus
primarily on my art.  By contributing to my campaign, you will help me
access the remote, bird rich areas that I plan to go to.  All funds raised
will go specifically towards my 5-month creative journey in the north.  I
am funding the other 4+ months of my trip independently.
The rough
break down of where your money is going for five months of northern Australia
travel:
ART
SUPPLIES:

If it
brings joy to your heart to donate, please do so.  With humility and deep gratitude, I thank you.
If you
can’t contribute financially, I would still love your support.  I’d love
to hear from you…who you are, how you are, how this project made you
feel.  And please share my project with people you love and care about

who might be inspired by it too.  Thank you!

You can email me at:  maloney.kt@gmail.com

Short Summary

Solrac Ventures is an animated series, featuring a very loud little pony, Solrac (Also known as Yaplap, for whatever reason). The show will feature many great artists from the ""Brony"" community, such as: Rina-Chan, The Living Tombstone, and ACRacebest. They will all provide their voices for their characters in the show. However, in order for the show to look GREAT, our lead animator, Kreid, must first gain the required pony-drawing knowledge to animate.

Kreid is an experienced animator, who began animating in 2006 in his spare time.  He has proven his abilities to animate flawlessly with his own online webseries, Oddball, writing, animating, and finalizing each second of his show.

Don't believe me, check it out:
Oddball
Some of his Pony-related works:

column2: qo=4"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" title=""TR"">BlackBolt Thunder [COMMISSION GIF]

column1: ZanonFly [COMMISION GIF]
Check out the rest of his work on Deviantart
<div>
By donating to this campaign, you will pave way for Kreid to practice drawing pony anatomy, and make Solrac Ventures the absolute BEST it can be!
STYLE DEVELOPMENT:
EPISODE TEASERS:
Kreid has also created thumbnails for the SCREAMING FU*KING COVERS:

REWARDS and PERKS

The $5 Perk
Lead Animator, Kreid, will doodle YOUR OC in Solrac Ventures style! You must provide him with reference! Doodle will not be colored, but will have light-shading.
The $15 Perk
Choose (1) of the 8 designs (drawn by Kreid) below, and we'll turn it into a cardboard cutout!! Cutout will arrive to your provided address in July. FREE SHIPPING!!
THE $30 PERK

Animator, Kreid, will draw YOUR OC in Solrac Ventures style! Afterwards, Solrac will transform it into a cardboard cutout! Use it as decoration for your home, or for a video! The possibilities are endless!! Cutout will arrive in July. FREE SHIPPING!!
THE $50 PERK
Choose (5) of the 8 designs (drawn by Kreid) below, and we'll turn them into cardboard cutouts!! Cutouts will arrive to your provided address in July. FREE SHIPPING!!
<div>
FREE BUTTONS!!
Choose ANY of the perks regarding cardboard cutouts, and receive 2 Solrac buttons, FREE!! (Buttons NOT sold seperately, and are not available for $5 Perk)
With your help, Kreid can develop a unique style for the show!! Not only that, but the funds will also aid him with purchasing better equipment (Wacom Cintiq)

If you don't have a way to donate, they're a plenty of other ways to help!
Such as:

SCREAM AT PEOPLE ON TWITTER ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN!!!

SCREAM AT PEOPLE ON EVERYWHERE ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN!!!

Short Summary

Are you crazy about all things cars? Perhaps you have a favorite from your childhood, or that one vehicle that you always wanted but could never afford. Maybe it was that first set of wheels and the first feelings of freedom that you want to live again. Well if any of the above describes you, welcome to AutoMania.

My name is Ken Chester Jr. and for the last 20 years I have been writing new vehicle reviews for major newspapers across the United States.  For the last 12 years I have been taking thousands of pictures of the vehicles I have reviewed for my newspaper column.  In addition, I have attended the major car shows around the United States – taking pictures of the unique and unusual vehicles that have been displayed.  Starting in 2007, I have also included automotive images that I have taken for the inventory of my online stores. I now want to share these with other automaniacs like me.

From these tens of thousands of automotive images I am building a place to allow the car crazies of the world to access, search and download images of the vehicles many have just dreamed about – production, concept, and specialty images – that you will NOT find anywhere else on the Internet!
If that’s not enough, I will provide you the tools to enable you to manage the many images you are going to want – designed to be right sized for ANY computer or mobile device you choose.

More you say?  OK – Since I still shoot upto 1,000 images a month of the best and newest vehicles in the marketplace, you can also choose to sign up to be notified when I upload new content (which is almost weekly).
What We Need

This project will create a searchable and downloadable database of over 60,000 images – complete with the image management tools built in.   Because I own the images, there will be no restrictions what so ever in their use.   To achieve this goal I need to raise $49,745.
The major expenses for this project are as follows:
Programming                       $25,000
Marketing &
Fees &
General &
Impact

This searchable and downloadable database of automotive images is just the first product in what will become an auto-centric on-line community of all things automotive.  Streaming video, audio, clubs and associations will all become part of an amazing concept called “AutoManiaCity”.

The eventual goal will be to have AutoManiaCity be THE place for ALL things automotive – not just images alone.  But even a city has to be carved out of the wilderness.. and settled.  This is where you come in.  By helping us to create this product, it gives us the capital to then fund the development of AutoManiaCity.
Looking for a new digital “home”?  Then AutoManiaCity will be your destination!
Other Ways You Can Help
Please be sure to spread the word to other “car crazies” and fellow “AutoManiacs” that you know.  I really would appreciate your help in getting the word out!

Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

","Short Summary

Are you crazy about all things cars? Perhaps you have a favorite from your childhood, or that one vehicle that you always wanted but could never afford. Maybe it was that first set of wheels and the first feelings of freedom that you want to live again. Well if any of the above describes you, welcome to AutoMania.

My name is Ken Chester Jr. and for the last 20 years I have been writing new vehicle reviews for major newspapers across the United States.  For the last 12 years I have been taking thousands of pictures of the vehicles I have reviewed for my newspaper column.  In addition, I have attended the major car shows around the United States – taking pictures of the unique and unusual vehicles that have been displayed.  Starting in 2007, I have also included automotive images that I have taken for the inventory of my online stores. I now want to share these with other automaniacs like me.

From these tens of thousands of automotive images I am building a place to allow the car crazies of the world to access, search and download images of the vehicles many have just dreamed about – production, concept, and specialty images – that you will NOT find anywhere else on the Internet!
If that’s not enough, I will provide you the tools to enable you to manage the many images you are going to want – designed to be right sized for ANY computer or mobile device you choose.

More you say?  OK – Since I still shoot upto 1,000 images a month of the best and newest vehicles in the marketplace, you can also choose to sign up to be notified when I upload new content (which is almost weekly).
What We Need

This project will create a searchable and downloadable database of over 60,000 images – complete with the image management tools built in.   Because I own the images, there will be no restrictions what so ever in their use.   To achieve this goal I need to raise $49,745.

Programming                       $25,000
Marketing & Advertising         $15,000
Fees & Perks                        $ 5,600
General & Administrative        $ 4,145
Impact

Looking for a new digital “home”?  Then AutoManiaCity will be your destination!

What is Wonderground Arts?

Wonderground Arts is an umbrella for mural work, stage/movie prop creation, and most importantly, the hand-crafted, travel-inspired clocks seen above! It is a colorful representation of happiness, beauty, and worldwide unity.

Jesse Pales, the owner / sole creator of Wonderground Arts, is a craftswoman, visual artist, and carpenter. Fueled by her interest in the arts, she takes design to a new level with the understanding that the prime focus of a piece is not just to make something ""look beautiful"", but also to infuse it with stunning visual appeal and passion. Dabbling the arts since the age of 5, she has decided to convert her hobbies into a fulfilling career. Jesse is also a mural artist, prop professional and graphic designer who has worked in carpentry and custom framing since age 16 and harnesses a grand set of artistic/ hardware tools and materials to boot.

The ultimate goal is to create ultra sensory gallery exhibits and take them all over the world. Wonderground Arts aims to transcend the typical form of show and transform an entire space into a three dimensional work of ""explorable"" art- eventually to be named the Wonderground Arts Experience.
Materials and Funding

Currently, Wonderground Arts has been working on a series of hand-crafted, functional clocks in the likeness of London's Big Ben. Unfortunately, between life, pets and rent, the funds are not quite there to complete the series, break out into the art world, or continue on to larger projects. If this campaign reaches it's goal of $5,000, Wonderground Arts will have the funds to purchase all of the MANY necessary materials to finalize the Big Ben series, start another, and pursue a real and passionately driven arts career that in time, promises to touch the hearts and lives of millions.
Ranging from trinkets and desktop clocks to custom full size creations, the rewards for all pledges are heartfelt, spectacular, and exciting.
<div>
Wonderground Arts and the World

Through arts, media and engineering, Wonderground Arts strives to remind people that even in times of hardship, beauty is to be found in all corners of the world. The goal is to spark hope and a sense of world wide unity in those that are willing to have a look, and eventually take that hope and spread it everywhere imaginable.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
Can't pledge? That's quite alright! A share or two will go a very long way. Any help you can give is highly appreciated.

","Sponsor the Exhibition & Vote Night on August 20, 2011so we can Support Emerging Artists!
GoGo be a Star!
Select your celebrity status & cover our overhead, so every single ticket we sell goes towards buying art!! Individual ticket sales will begin on July 1st (stay tuned)!
Have you ever stood in a chilly art museum and wondered ""How did this stuff get here?"" or ""Who decided that was art?""
By sponsoring  Gift of Gift of you
can answer both of those questions.

Gift of Gift of (or GoGo) was started last year as a way to give young art lovers a chance to support emerging photographers and have a great time doing it. Each year GoGo hosts an annual Exhibition & Vote Party for folks who love art and want to have a say in what works are ""museum worthy."" The exhibition features photographs found through an open call for entries (open until May 27, no entry fee). The photographs are by artists of all ages from around the world who are all just starting out and are looking for the boost that comes when their work is acquired by renowned museum. Money from Party ticket sales are pooled together to purchase as many of the exhibited artworks. Partygoers vote on the art to decide what should be offered as a gift of Gift of Gift of.

As a sponsor you are empowering folks who love art but might not have the means to acquire and donate it alone. Collectively they can support emerging artists and have a say in what belongs in a museum. Sponsor Gift of Gift of and demystify the museum.
Last summer
Gift of Gift of hosted its first Exhibition & Vote Party, with over 100
partygoers voting, Gift of Gift of 2010 collectively
purchased 9 of the 14 photographs exhibited. Last year's GoGo artists
were from across the US, with one from Australia.Gift of Gift of's mission is to offer young art patrons an
egalitarian opportunity to impact large collecting institutions and to
aid emerging artists at a critical point in their careers.

The exhibition is a chance for emerging photographers to gain exposure.The party brings artists and art lovers together, encouraging them into a talk about the work and lobby for votes for their favorites, while having glamorous good time.
The voting give art lovers a chance to have a tangible impact on a large collecting institution.
We want the cost of every ticket to go towards buying art. The more tickets sold, the more art we can buy. Make this happen by covering the cost of exhibition materials, shipping, and the party.
Where The $$$ Goes:

All funds raised through IndieGoGo will go towards the incredibly unglamorous aspects of organizing an exhibition and a party. Covering the cost of ballot boxes and exhibition materials, from nails to spackle, shipping costs. It will go towards web hosting and membership to Fractured Atlas.  We will be renting fans and buying ice to battle the sweltering August heat in Houston
column2: paying a DJ and taco truck to provide vibes and delicious snacks to voters and artists alike
column3: printing flyers to get the word out when tickets go on sale and when the GoGo 2011 artists are chosen! Moral of the story: it will allow us to host a great exhibition and an awesome party,

Our Story
<span style=""font-style: italic
is an idea.  One where the various talented artists in our local area
can come together, share their passion for the arts and make new friends
and colleagues.  We hope to elevate Central Florida’s talent pool
through collaborative efforts.
We are two young professionals not far removed from being recent college
graduates.  A Graphic Designer and a Filmmaker professionally.  A
Renaissance Woman and a Storyteller naturally.  Together we are starting
our own production company and working hard at breaking into the
industry.  Slowly but steadily we are making a name for ourselves
locally.  I still have to work another job to pay the bills currently,
but we are on our way and doing just fine on our own.
What we're here asking for help with is our event
column3: >Wrecked A Collision of Art.  What started out  simply as a premiere my first short film,

column1: has grown into an effort to strengthen our local art community in
three ways.  First is to give other artists the ability to share their
work instead of trying to showcase just 1 filmmaker.  Now we are
presenting several of them, along with some fine artists, a photographer, performance
artists, and a musician.  This pool of talent consists of artists
ranging from student to seasoned professional.  Now, of course the show
is open to the public, but we will be seeking the attendance of students from local art
schools and local professionals to provide a networking atmosphere to
connect the two.  Finally, a hope of ours is to get the varied artistic
and creative communities to become more aware of each other.  We want
to inspire some cross pollination of creative endeavors and local
support.  Who knows what wonders and monstrosities could be created?

The Impact

Aside from the aforementioned effects on the local art community.  We have partnered with Creative Clay.  If you haven't watched the video above I would recommend doing so.  I'm gonna let them speak for themselves through their mission statement here and the video you see above.

""Creative Clay’s mission is to make the arts
accessible for every interested member of the Tampa Bay community
regardless of age, gender, ability and/or race. Since 1995, Creative
Clay has been providing local artists with developmental, physical
and/or emotional disabilities an opportunity to pursue their passion for
art making. Our arts programs consist of studio and community based
activities for exploring unique personal realities in an inventive,
professional environment.
Creative Clay is committed to promoting the work
created by its member artists through bimonthly art exhibitions in our
downtown gallery and various public venues throughout the greater Tampa

Bay region."" 

We have offered ourselves up as one of these venues.  Along with the artists gathered we will be displaying art from Creative Clay members.  We are hoping to raise money for Creative Clay as well through various methods through out the event.  Some art has been donated so we may have a silent auction for the work leading up to the event.  The day of there will be a raffle for products and services donated by local businesses, professionals, artisans and vendors.  We are seeking out sponsorships for advertising space as well.  We would like to be able to donate all this along with ticket sales to Creative Clay. 

The money raised for Creative Clay will be an invaluable asset to them.  They will use it for any number of necessities such as art supplies for their members to updating their gallery which in need of repair.  That will include getting them up the ADA standards.  As it stands right now they have doors that are very difficult to operate for many of their members.
What We Need

Overhead, that's what we are looking for help with.  There is work to make this event happen and a lot of out of pocket money that we can't necessarily afford to put out there.  We have been finding ways including (but not limited to) begging, pleading, borrowing and bartering.  And thanks to several kind hearted and like minded sponsors we have been able to get some of the necessities for reduced costs.  Here is a list of things that need to be covered.

column5: > $800 - Definitely a big deal and a must have.  Studio @620 In St. Petersburg Florida has secured the date of Saturday July 30th, 2011 for the show and has given us the week prior to showcase the artwork in their gallery.  They have the space we need, the projection equipment to show the films, the hanging system for the artwork and are providing a cash bar.  In our search to find a location we were met with prices ranging from no less than $3000 and upwards of $9000.  Studio @620 has a much more reasonable rate of $800 to use their space and are a big part of the local community.  We are very happy that they are on board with this project.

> $400-800 - Studio @620 can hold around 170 people when factoring in the seating for the film portion of the show.  We don't expect every patron to buy a shirt but we do need to have a variety of sizes for both men and women.  Our research has brought us to around $300-400 for 100 shirts.  If you look to the right you'll see that shirts are a part of the perks for donating to the campaign so we have to factor in you guys as well.  Either way there is a possibility of needing almost 200 shirts.  We are in talks with a local vendor who may be willing to do them at cost allowing us more profit from each shirt which will go to Creative Clay.  Nothing is finalized though so we will update as that info becomes available.

> $1000 - This is also very important.  Without effective marketing we can't get people in the door.  There are many things that need to be designed and printed such as: event programs, flyers, posters, post cards, mailers and so on.  Thankfully we have a few graphic designers on our team so no charge for that part, but the printing is where the money comes in.  And we did shoot a 3 minute short to help promote the show virally through the social media and the internet.  Thankfully we got some great actors who were willing to help our cause for free and Larry at Production Services and Systems helped us out on some equipment as well as a location.  But there were still some expenses involved to complete the production.

> $250 - Our musician and dancers are doing their thing for free and are local to Florida, but not the Tampa bay area.  We need to help them cover their travel expenses like gas and possibly room and board.  We have some people that may be able to provide a place to stay for them, but again, it's not finalized so we can't count on it just yet.  Will update as time goes on.fd

column2:
>

I know that we aren't asking for that total amount estimated above.  But we have been very lucky so far on finding some helpful, motivated and like minded people to help us out.  We believe that will continue and that we can do it for less than $2850.  So we are only seeking $2500 here. 

Our hope is to cover enough of these operating costs so that we can donate as much as possible to Creative Clay.  If for some reason we don't reach this goal, the show will still go on, it will just come down to how much we can help Creative Clay without putting ourselves in the hole.

If we exceed our goal, then every dollar over what we pay out will go to Creative Clay.  We are not taking any profit for ourselves from this campaign or event.  Monetary profit is not the point.  Helping our community in as many ways possible, is.  I hope you feel the same and can find it in within yourself and your budget to donate to this campaign.  Every dollar helps.

column1:
What You Get

You will definitely feel a sense of pride in yourself and your community for helping this campaign along.  But if that isn't enough for you, we are offering a range of perks with various donation amounts listed to the right.  You'll notive the titles are related to a ""Detective"" kind of vibe.  This is because we have chosen a Film Noire as the theme for the show.  That theme doesn't dictate what the artwork or films consists of, but simply our method of getting attention.  Why you may ask?  Well in the spirit of artistic freedom that Wrecked stands for, because we felt like it.  And as a filmmaker myself, it was a style I had not yet done.  So I took the opportunity to try something I had never done before.  You'll find the link to the promotional video here soon.  I hope you like it.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please pass this along to anyone and everyone who may be willing to help out a good cause.  To anyone with passion for the arts.  To anyone with pride in their local communities.
If you are in the local Tampa Bay/St Petersburg area (or don't mind the travel) then please come on out the event yourself and see what the local art community has to offer.

Performers $250 - Our musician and dancers are doing their thing for free and are local to Florida, but not the Tampa bay area.  We need to help them cover their travel expenses like gas and possibly room and board.  We have some people that may be able to provide a place to stay for them, but again, it's not finalized so we can't count on it just yet.  Will update as time goes on.fd
TOTAL (estimated) - $2850

I know that we aren't asking for that total amount estimated above.  But we have been very lucky so far on finding some helpful, motivated and like minded people to help us out.  We believe that will continue and that we can do it for less than $2850.  So we are only seeking $2500 here.  Our hope is to cover enough of these operating costs so that we can donate as much as possible to Creative Clay.  If for some reason we don't reach this goal, the show will still go on, it will just come down to how much we can help Creative Clay without putting ourselves in the hole.If we exceed our goal, then every dollar over what we pay out will go to Creative Clay.  We are not taking any profit for ourselves from this campaign or event.  Monetary profit is not the point.  Helping our community in as many ways possible, is.  I hope you feel the same and can find it in within yourself and your budget to donate to this campaign.  Every dollar helps.

What You GetYou will definitely feel a sense of pride in yourself and your community for helping this campaign along.  But if that isn't enough for you, we are offering a range of perks with various donation amounts listed to the right.  You'll notive the titles are related to a ""Detective"" kind of vibe.  This is because we have chosen a Film Noire as the theme for the show.  That theme doesn't dictate what the artwork or films consists of, but simply our method of getting attention.  Why you may ask?  Well in the spirit of artistic freedom that Wrecked stands for, because we felt like it.  And as a filmmaker myself, it was a style I had not yet done.  So I took the opportunity to try something I had never done before.  You'll find the link to the promotional video here soon.  I hope you like it.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please pass this along to anyone and everyone who may be willing to help out a good cause.  To anyone with passion for the arts.  To anyone with pride in their local communities.
If you are in the local Tampa Bay/St Petersburg area (or don't mind the travel) then please come on out the event yourself and see what the local art community has to offer.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Who We Are
Since 1996,
the Neon Museum has been dedicated to collecting, preserving, studying and
exhibiting iconic Las Vegas signs for educational, historical, arts and
cultural enrichment. Where possible, we fully restore select signage in order
to preserve the beauty of the signs and their message, as well as reintegrate
the signage into the community. Full sign restoration involves replacing broken
bulbs and neon, updating electrical, and repainting the sign cabinet. Many of our
restored signs have been installed throughout the city, as public art or as
part of the museum’s Neon Boneyard exhibition.
For the very first time, the Neon Museum is
going to attempt a partial restoration…and we need your help! The Desert Rose
Motel sign is one of the largest and most striking motel signs in our
collection. We will apply conservation methods to the sign in order to
rehabilitate and stabilize the sign and its design without fully restoring the
cabinet. This will lower costs, take less time, and simplify future
conservation initiatives. Repainting stabilizes a sign, removes rust or
blemishes, protects painted detailing and conserves the overall façade.
We need your
help to conserve and protect the Desert Rose Motel sign! We’ve already raised
$10,000 but it’s not enough. We need approximately $50,000 to resurface and
repaint the 1960 Desert Rose Motel cabinet and reattach the elegant rose
trellises to the billboard-style sign. Repainting a sign like the Desert Rose

Motel protects the sign from the elements and secures its long-term stability.

What You Get

Donate $250 or more and you receive tickets to a private party in the Neon Boneyard to unveil the newly painted Desert Rose sign. Complimentary cocktails and small bites will be available. Limited space is available for this unveiling party.

For donations $50 and up, you will receive a custom Desert Rose t-shirt (don't worry, we will get your shirt size after the campaign ends,) a vintage Desert Rose postcard and a two-inch sticker. 
For donations more than $100,  you will score a Desert Rose tote bag in addition to the other level perks.
<b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
Neon signage
is very fragile. Neon tubing breaks, paint flakes and fades, metal bends, and
the message gets lost. Iconic signs that have distinct shapes or features often
escape obscurity because they are easily recognizable. However, when a
simplified shape like the large rectangular cabinet of the Desert Rose Motel
loses its paint and tubing, the entire sign disappears. Like a massive canvas,
the Desert Rose is distinctive for its striking hand-painted lettering and
floral trellis detailing that makes the daytime visual experience as beautiful
as the night. The Desert Rose sign must be repainted in order to preserve these
one-of-a-kind design elements so that visitors to the Neon Museum will be able
to appreciate its beauty and historical significance for many years to come.
Designed by the Young Electric Sign Company,
the large pole-mounted sign was originally situated on the southern end of the
Las Vegas Strip, drawing in visitors traveling into the city along Highway 91
from Los Angeles. The Desert Rose Motel opened in 1953 and remained in
operation until 1995 when the building was demolished to make way for the Monte
Carlo. The bright blue billboard with trailing flowers was a fixture of the
vintage Las Vegas skyline.
Contributing to the Desert Rose Motel sign
campaign will put you at the forefront of sign conservation. Your contribution
will help the museum start the next phase of its mission and allow museum
visitors to better appreciate the art form that is the sign. <i>You will be
helping jumpstart a whole new era of the Neon Museum and we can’t do it without
you!
Credits:
Video features images from the Joseph W. McGee Photograph Collection, Neon Museum.
Video production created by Jason Harper.

What this project is about
We are combining high technology and high art to create
something very special â€“ the Rygo. Standing 2 meters tall, it will be the
largest such 3D print of any type in North America (quite possibly the Western
hemisphere) and will be installed for all the world to see at Groppâ€™s Gallery
of Vancouver, Canada. Crowdfunding the Rygo reflects the best qualities of
Vancouver â€“ organic design supported by a grassroots movement. This is also an
international effort! The Rygo will be printed in Italy by Enrico Diniâ€™s
DShape, itself the largest 3D printer of its kind, measuring 6 x 6 x 8 meters
(20 x 20 x 27 ft). The Rygo was designed by famous 3D designer and sculptor
Bathsheba Grossman of California, utilizing esoteric math and an artistic touch
to craft a piece that would have been un-makeable by any other means.
Everyone in this campaign truly believes that 3D printing
will shake up everything you thought you knew about design, construction, manufacturing,
architecture, sculptureâ€¦.you name it. We hope you feel the same. Every contribution is going towards a leap in technology that
happens only once a decade.
What you will get
We have lots of awesome rewards. Although the Rygo will be
located in Vancouver, you will able to see and interact with the Rygo via the
internet. For $15 you will be given a password to our website and see the Rygo *live* via
webcam. Not only that, you will be able to change the colour and intensity of
the light inside the Rygo. We have the leafychain designed by me for $20. These
will be printed by our friends in New York, Buildatron, who have just released

a new 3D printer onto the market. 




We have actual pieces made the DShape! For
$30 you will get a chunk of DShape print material â€“ be the first in your city
to have a piece of history! From $75 to $300 we have small, medium and large 3D prints
of the Rygo made of clear plastic. You can put it on your necklace, put it on your desk.

For $500 and above, you can print off your own model! Say you have something from thingiverse.com or Google Sketchup? We can print it for you in solid rock with the DShape. Model must be 50x50x50 cm and have walls thicker than 5 cm. Please message us with a design that you would want printed.


For $1000 we have this lamp
designed by JF Brandon. Called â€œNicheâ€, it measures 1 meter tall (3 ft) and can stand
outside to illuminate the path or inside as a tablelamp. It was made using

Voronoi diagrams to make non-repeating holes to allow light through. 




Where the donations are going

3D printing, shipping and installing the Rygo will cost close to $10,000. This includes Custom Duties and Taxes. 3D printing the smaller versions of the Rygo, the Leafychain, the Rochain or the Niche are a significant expense that must be covered. If we don't meet our target, we can print a smaller Rygo. But size matters! I don't think a smaller Statue of Liberty would have had the same impact as it did. Nor a smaller Eiffel Tower. And it certainly wouldn't be ""the largest"" 3D print in North America. The DShape is a 6 x 6 x 8 meter 3D printer.... so if w
