Gulf Coast Artists Alliance, Inc. (GCAA), is a non-profit 501(c)(3) membership based organization, operating out of St. Petersburg Florida for the past 10 years. The mission of our organization is to provide local artists of all disciplines an opportunity to network, share resources, conduct workshops and classes, and hold exhibitions. St. Pete Artworks, our co-operative retail art gallery for local artists in Downtown St. Petersburg, treats visitors to a feast of high-quality painting, sculpture, jewelry, mixed media and more. Our second location, GCAA Creative Zone, is a combination of art studios for working artists, a classroom, and meeting space in Pinellas Park. The GCAA general annual membership is comprised of an average of 50 primarily visual artists and art educators
column2: performers, authors, musicians, and other like-minded individuals are welcome and generally comprise about 5% of our membership. An average of 21 of the visual artist members are also members of our co-operative art gallery, St. Pete ArtWorks.

column1: GCAA originally started as The Sculptural Art Center of Dunedin in 2002. In 2004 we change the name to Gulf Coast Artists’ Alliance Inc. to reflect a change of location and program focus. After a nomadic life in several locations throughout Pinellas county, years of meeting out of members’ homes, and various shifts in programing, in 2011 we finally settled in the City of St. Petersburg because we’ve found the city to be a vibrant and stimulating environment. Our goal is to grow our membership and become a strong and vital support system for local artists, while offering the citizens of St. Petersburg and beyond the opportunity to experience our creative expression, camaraderie, and enthusiasm. Support for GCAA has come primarily from memberships, as well as art sales commissions, private donors, and small grants. GCAA is powered 100% by volunteers and has been since its formation.

Due to dramatic increases in rent and gentrification in downtown St. Petersburg, we have been forced to move our location several times. We have not been able to afford a space large enough to have our studios, classes and gallery under one roof. In 2019, we opened the GCAA Creative Zone in the neighboring city of Pinellas Park. We would have preferred to stay in St. Petersburg, but the skyrocketing rents prohibited this at the time. Now, with leases at both locations coming to an end, we have been able to locate a space on Central Avenue in St. Petersburg large enough to accommodate both our co-operative gallery, St. Pete ArtWorks, and our art studios and classroom. It is only two blocks away from our existing retail location, so we expect minimal loss of retail revenue as a result the move. The studio artists will have more public exposure, and more visitors will mean more opportunity for class and workshop registrations. A new member gallery will be added in the classroom area and hallway, giving all of our general members more exhibition opportunities. We are all excited about the move to this improved, centralized location!
This move does not come without additional expenses. We need to raise $5000 to:
1. Purchase and install track lighting
2. Construct walls for artwork display spaces
3. Build out studios
2. Clean and Paint
3. New signage

Most of the labor is being done by volunteers. Also, there will be considerable moving of existing walls and fixtures from our two current locations, which must be done in a timely manner to minimize double rent expense. We have done this before, each time with unique challenges, but we have overcome these challenges and made lemonade from lemons every time.

We have a wide range of perks for our contributors. Original artwork, assorted notecards and prints, unique one-of-a-kind journals, mystery gift bags containing artwork by an artist of your choice, jewelry, and workshops. High level contributors will receive name recognition on our website and printed materials, as well as a room named for the donor at our new location. Whatever money we raise will go toward the improvements and moving expenses necessary to make our dreams for GCAA a reality.

If you are not able to contribute at this time, no worries! You can help to spread the word by telling your friends about this great group of artists living and working in your community, and our need. We’ll appreciate you sharing our campaign on your social media sites using the Indiegogo share tools.

The GCAA general annual membership is comprised of an average of 50 primarily visual artists and art educators
column2: performers, authors, musicians, and other like-minded individuals are welcome and generally comprise about 5% of our membership. An average of 21 of the visual artist members are also members of our co-operative art gallery, St. Pete ArtWorks.

column1: GCAA originally started as The Sculptural Art Center of Dunedin in 2002. In 2004 we change the name to Gulf Coast Artists’ Alliance Inc. to reflect a change of location and program focus. After a nomadic life in several locations throughout Pinellas county, years of meeting out of members’ homes, and various shifts in programing, in 2011 we finally settled in the City of St. Petersburg because we’ve found the city to be a vibrant and stimulating environment. Our goal is to grow our membership and become a strong and vital support system for local artists, while offering the citizens of St. Petersburg and beyond the opportunity to experience our creative expression, camaraderie, and enthusiasm. Support for GCAA has come primarily from memberships, as well as art sales commissions, private donors, and small grants. GCAA is powered 100% by volunteers and has been since its formation.

Due to dramatic increases in rent and gentrification in downtown St. Petersburg, we have been forced to move our location several times. We have not been able to afford a space large enough to have our studios, classes and gallery under one roof. In 2019, we opened the GCAA Creative Zone in the neighboring city of Pinellas Park. We would have preferred to stay in St. Petersburg, but the skyrocketing rents prohibited this at the time. Now, with leases at both locations coming to an end, we have been able to locate a space on Central Avenue in St. Petersburg large enough to accommodate both our co-operative gallery, St. Pete ArtWorks, and our art studios and classroom. It is only two blocks away from our existing retail location, so we expect minimal loss of retail revenue as a result the move. The studio artists will have more public exposure, and more visitors will mean more opportunity for class and workshop registrations. A new member gallery will be added in the classroom area and hallway, giving all of our general members more exhibition opportunities. We are all excited about the move to this improved, centralized location!
This move does not come without additional expenses. We need to raise $5000 to:
1. Purchase and install track lighting
2. Construct walls for artwork display spaces
3. Build out studios
2. Clean and Paint
3. New signage

Most of the labor is being done by volunteers. Also, there will be considerable moving of existing walls and fixtures from our two current locations, which must be done in a timely manner to minimize double rent expense. We have done this before, each time with unique challenges, but we have overcome these challenges and made lemonade from lemons every time.

We have a wide range of perks for our contributors. Original artwork, assorted notecards and prints, unique one-of-a-kind journals, mystery gift bags containing artwork by an artist of your choice, jewelry, and workshops. High level contributors will receive name recognition on our website and printed materials, as well as a room named for the donor at our new location. Whatever money we raise will go toward the improvements and moving expenses necessary to make our dreams for GCAA a reality.

If you are not able to contribute at this time, no worries! You can help to spread the word by telling your friends about this great group of artists living and working in your community, and our need. We’ll appreciate you sharing our campaign on your social media sites using the Indiegogo share tools.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Saint Petersburg, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/artworks-on-the-move/pica

Our Story

We are five queer Bay Area artists exploring the phenomenon of re-naming within our communities in a collaborative, witty, charming, silly, sexy, charged, gripping performance that you will never forget! Join us as we delve into the ABYSS OF NAMES (to which dead names return and from which new names spring) and investigate naming in relationship to time, place and visibility, identity tourism and consumption, and magic.  Collaboratively we will create a multi-media performance that challenges performance genre segregation by integrating dance, storytelling, experimental music, video, theater, sound, games facilitation, and audience participation.  

Beyond our devotion to our respective art forms, we are dedicated organizers and agents of change within our communities. With our art, we give voice to radical queer perspective and challenge the dominant paradigm.  

The idea for this collaborative was sparked by a merging of artists through our devotion to radical organizing. We found peers and solace, reason to take voice in this way.

The Impact

We hope that performing our individual truths about our names will enrich audience members' consciousness about queer identity and the violence and liberatory power of names. Through participatory activities, audience members will be further challenged to consider the politics and potential of naming.

We hope to open an empowered dialog about an unbroached social phenomenon while upholding our integrity as agents of social justice. Through our performance, we hope to encourage personal and community transformation toward collective liberation.

Specifically, we want to defray costs from: -printing, -transportation, -props, -equipment.None of us make our living from our art, but we want to make projects like this a sustainable part of our lives. Please support our vision of a nurturing, thoughtful and responsible queer/art community!

So its coming down to the wire and we are onto the best parts of the build. The body, lighting and sound. We need more help to make the playa bound pig...well, just that- playa bound.

Already there are new brake components, master cylinder, wheel cylinders and lines. We got the cart running great with a new starter, alternator, voltage regulator, belt, carb rebuild, valve adjustment, plugs, oil and filter.....

So the hard part is done, and now its onto the good stuff! The body is going to be made of thinner sheet metal bent around 1 inch round frame tubing, with recycled goods for the snout and tail. The legs with be metal as well, with more support going into frame work. We just started welding it this week, 7/15.

There will be more support for passengers on either side so there will be two ride-alongs as well as two seats, four passengers total. The windshield is being replaced with plexiglass and the front end reassembled one the snout, ears, and aviator windshield is replaced. We are also swapping suspension pieces from a heavy duty 1972 Cushman Haulster + new shocks.

Alright, enough about whats there. We need a little help with the sheet metal, steel stock, paint, fuel, lighting, and the trailer. We are looking to build up a super duty harbor freight trailer up to spec just for Mr. Piggy. We have already spent much of our own money this one and were looking for a little extra help to get it playa bound. So please take a look at the incentives and donate what you can.We are so thankful for any and all donations and we will be so happy if we can reach our goal!

My name is Daniel Sheehan and I am a recent graduate of the University of Hartford's, Hartford Art School. I earned my Bachelor of Fine Arts with a concentration in Printmaking and Sculpture. Since leaving school, I have been looking for a space and opportunity to continue my art and make a name for myself.

Graduating was like falling into the shark infested waters of the ""real world"". Come to find out I wasn't the only one drowning in countless unanswered questions. Many artists often wave the white flag too early on in life and give up on their dream.  My plan is to make sure that artists have a place to continue experimenting and developing their art while working in a collaborative atmosphere.  Shark Tank Studio would also be a gateway for these emerging artists to show off their stuff and get exposure.  

My reason for creating Shark Tank Studio is to create an opportunity to stay connected with a select group of artists whom I have worked with and come to admire. I may be their number one fan now, but I know you are going to be big fans too once you get to see their work! The studio will be set up in Whitman, MA, a central location for the current group of emerging artists to work.  

With your help Shark Tank Studio will be able to purchase its first press. This will enable a group of artists to not only continue to pursue their passion, but prosper while doing it. These artists deserve the chance to have their work displayed. The best way to get it there is with your help! Shark Tank’s first press (that the studio has high hopes to purchase) would allow artists to work in a range of techniques like intaglio (etching), relief, monotype and lithography.

If we can’t meet our goal of $5250.00, the money we do fundraise will go to directly into the studio in different ways. We would still be able to purchase other printing materials like blocks and plates for the actual printing process, tools, or even a smaller table top printing press model. We just want to make Shark Tank Studio a reality and appreciate your support!

Please help by donating what you can, or just simply spreading the word about the project through social media or word of mouth.

Follow us on Instagram for constant updates @shark_tank_studio

column19: >Hello! My name's Jen Delos Reyes. I was born in the city of Winnipeg, and educated first in its local music scene of the mid-90’s infused with the energy of Riot grrrl and DIY, and then in its university. How I work today as an artist, educator, writer, and radical community arts organizer is rooted in what I learned in my formative years as a show promoter, listener, creator of zines, and band member.

>I spend most of my time thinking about socially engaged art, whether it is through my role as the director of Open Engagement, a national conference on the subject, or teaching about it in the Art in Social Practice Program at Portland State University. For the last year and a half I have been focusing my research, writing, and speaking engagements around the importance of art in everyday life and artists who have used their creative practices to live with meaning and purpose.

column36: >I'm Going to Live the Life I Sing About in my Song: How Artists Make and Live Lives of Meaning is a book that will provide inspiration for readers to see how they can creatively shape their own lives with purpose and meaning. It looks at how artists have used their creativity to shape the world they want to see and taken steps towards creating the lives they want to live.

column19: >There are many people that one can look to for help living well, whether that be Martha Stewart, Elizabeth Gilbert, or countless self-help books about improving your life. As an artist myself I am choosing to look to other artists.

>Artists have a way of provoking new forms of being. They examine and challenge the ways that we live and work. They propose alternative approaches, and suggest ways of navigating and negotiating existing systems. This book will provide inspiration to readers to see how they can also creatively shape their own lives with purpose and meaning, modify systems and structures, and in turn change the world we inhabit together.

>The book will give an inside look into these artists daily lives through in-depth on-site visits, interviews, images of their homes and workplaces, and a foreword that will unpack the history of the artists impulse toward art and everyday life. The book will be a full-color document that will lay bare the quotidian as well as monumental aspects of their work and lives. It will give an inside look at how these artists approach not only their work, but their days, schedules, relationships and how they live.

column19: >Many of the artists that blur the boundary between art and life have an approach that is not merely a project, but, in the words of John Cage, they treat art as an “experimental station in which one tries out living.” In these experiments artists are shaping the world around them through their art. We can look to artists to show us how to creatively shape our daily existence. They can model for us the worlds we want to live in.

>This book will serve as a road map of where others have been - through a series of interviews with visionary artists/philosophers/thinkers- towards creating the lives we want to live and the worlds we want to see through the creativity of artists who have used their work to make and live lives of meaning. The book will examine the social movements, cultural theory, and philosophies that were influencing these artists from political activism, intentional living, pioneering figures, and Eastern philosophies. It will trace a history of artists who have worked on the border of art and life and culminate in chapters looking at the work of  Fritz Haeg, David Horvitz, J. Morgan Puett,Ben Kinmont, and Mierle Laderman Ukeles. These artists use daily acts of living to connect their artistic practice to their life values and philosophies.

column19: >“When I was growing up this tendency to move around seemed to be related to a sense of restlessness or boredom. But now it is more about movements, routes, and channels of distribution.”

>David Horvitz is a Fluxus inspired artist living in Brooklyn, NY. His work has touched on relationships, social networks, public knowledge, mail art, and collaboration. Some of his projects have taken on forms that include Wikipedia, packages, hairballs, posters, photography, fundraising, and mushroom hunting. Horvitz is an artist whose work flows seamlessly into his everyday life using the virtual sphere. His instagram feed is a wash with images of mailed drift wood, foraged mushrooms, meals, and his sometimes interspecies collaborator, his cat.
>“Art can happen anywhere, even at the core of your daily life.”

>Gardener. Dancer. Artist. Architect. Teacher. Fritz Haeg’s work has included edible gardens, public dances, educational environments, animal architecture, domestic gatherings, urban parades, temporary encampments, documentary videos, publications, exhibitions, websites, and occasionally buildings for people. Recent projects include Edible Estates – an international series of public domestic edible gardens
column20: Animal Estates – a housing initiative for native wildlife in cities
column21: Sundown Schoolhouse – an itinerant educational program, which evolved out of the Sundown Salon gatherings at his geodesic home base in the hills of Los Angeles, and the new traveling project series of Domestic Integrities.

column19: >Morgan Puett is an interdisciplinary artist who “curates” her refrigerator. She looks at everyday domesticity as a potent site of creativity and education.

>She is an artist, cultural producer, fashion designer, and Co-founder and Director of Mildred’s Lane Historical Society and Museum. Mildred’s Lane is a 92–acre social practice mecca situated in rural Pennsylvania, designed to collectively create and discuss new pedagogical models of being in the world with regards to the environment, systems of labor, forms of dwelling, ethics, and sociality. Mildred’s Lane is a long-term, collaborative project that promotes living as a creative research practice through a revolving cast of residents, fellows, visiting artists, scholars, and social practitioners.
>“Sometimes a nicer sculpture is making a living for your family.”

>Ben Kinmont is an artist, publisher, and antiquarian bookseller. Kinmont's work is based in real-time exchanges such as meals, conversations, and gestures. In 1996 he began his publishing project, Antinomian Press, publishing material, often distributed for free. Kinmont also has an ongoing antiquarian bookselling business, begun in 1998, that specializes in books and manuscripts about domestic economy and food.
>“That is what maintenance is, trying to listen to the hum of living. A feeling of being alive, breath to breath.”
>Mierle Laderman Ukeles is an artist whose work is about maintenance, relationships, and care. She looks at the overlooked, the garbage, the daily chores, the workers.

>Since 1970 she has been the unsalaried artist-in-residence for New York City's Sanitation Department where she builds and orchestrates major public projects that explore the social and ecological issues of waste management.
>One risk of the project is that I am not releasing this book through an academic press. However I am choosing to see this as an opportunity.
>Most, if not all academic presses operate on model that does not compensate their contributors.
>I believe that all participants need to be compensated for their work and I am looking for support from the Kickstarter community who believe both in this project and in fair wages for work.
>What if my address changes before the book is released?
> Before any shipments are made we will verify the address in case of change.

column1: ","Summary

Hello! My name's Jen Delos Reyes. I was born in the city of Winnipeg, and educated first in its local music scene of the mid-90’s infused with the energy of Riot grrrl and DIY, and then in its university. How I work today as an artist, educator, writer, and radical community arts organizer is rooted in what I learned in my formative years as a show promoter, listener, creator of zines, and band member.

I spend most of my time thinking about socially engaged art, whether it is through my role as the director of Open Engagement, a national conference on the subject, or teaching about it in the Art in Social Practice Program at Portland State University. For the last year and a half I have been focusing my research, writing, and speaking engagements around the importance of art in everyday life and artists who have used their creative practices to live with meaning and purpose.

I'm Going to Live the Life I Sing About in my Song: How Artists Make and Live Lives of Meaning is a book that will provide inspiration for readers to see how they can creatively shape their own lives with purpose and meaning. It looks at how artists have used their creativity to shape the world they want to see and taken steps towards creating the lives they want to live.

There are many people that one can look to for help living well, whether that be Martha Stewart, Elizabeth Gilbert, or countless self-help books about improving your life. As an artist myself I am choosing to look to other artists.

Artists have a way of provoking new forms of being. They examine and challenge the ways that we live and work. They propose alternative approaches, and suggest ways of navigating and negotiating existing systems. This book will provide inspiration to readers to see how they can also creatively shape their own lives with purpose and meaning, modify systems and structures, and in turn change the world we inhabit together.

The book will give an inside look into these artists daily lives through in-depth on-site visits, interviews, images of their homes and workplaces, and a foreword that will unpack the history of the artists impulse toward art and everyday life. The book will be a full-color document that will lay bare the quotidian as well as monumental aspects of their work and lives. It will give an inside look at how these artists approach not only their work, but their days, schedules, relationships and how they live.
Images from onsite interviews with artists.

Many of the artists that blur the boundary between art and life have an approach that is not merely a project, but, in the words of John Cage, they treat art as an “experimental station in which one tries out living.” In these experiments artists are shaping the world around them through their art. We can look to artists to show us how to creatively shape our daily existence. They can model for us the worlds we want to live in.

This book will serve as a road map of where others have been - through a series of interviews with visionary artists/philosophers/thinkers- towards creating the lives we want to live and the worlds we want to see through the creativity of artists who have used their work to make and live lives of meaning. The book will examine the social movements, cultural theory, and philosophies that were influencing these artists from political activism, intentional living, pioneering figures, and Eastern philosophies. It will trace a history of artists who have worked on the border of art and life and culminate in chapters looking at the work of  Fritz Haeg, David Horvitz, J. Morgan Puett,Ben Kinmont, and Mierle Laderman Ukeles. These artists use daily acts of living to connect their artistic practice to their life values and philosophies.
The Book

I am not releasing this book through an academic press not only to have full control over the design decisions, but more importantly because I believe that all contributors need to be compensated for their work.

I am releasing this book as a 200 page full color, case bound book with cloth cover. I want to create a beautiful book that will highlight the work of the amazing artists I am featuring, some of which have only a handful of publications available about their work.
eBook
There are going to be two digital versions of the book:
1. Full-content HTML-based web edition of the book optimized for the iPad.
2. A PDF version that will be compatible with iPad and Kindle.
Funds- Goal: $25,000.00
The initial research for the project was supported by the Hyde Park Art Center in Chicago in the summer of 2013.
In 2014 I received a small Regional Arts and Culture Grant that has made it possible to travel and conduct the interviews with the five featured artists.
Now what is needed are funds for:

Paying everyone involved in the book. Paying the contributing artists. Paying people who are working alongside me on the book: professional editor, project manager/documentarian, designers, and research assistant—$7,750.
Production of the book in a run of 1000 printed locally in Portland, OR—$15,000.00
A portion of the funds raised will be put towards allowing me to set aside a few months to exclusively work on the writing for the book—$4000,00
$2,250 of the $25,000 is the crowd funding fees.
The estimated timeline is that interviews will be wrapped by the end of 2014. Intensive writing will happen in 2015. Book to be released in 2016.
Perks
You can be part of making this project happen! You can support the project at any rate, starting at $5, and any donation of $37 or more pre-orders your copy of the book.
If you can contribute more, there are reciprocal benefits that include signed copies of the book, limited editions, and more.
See right for the full details.
Featured Artists
Images from onsite interviews with artists.
David Horvitz
“When I was growing up this tendency to move around seemed to be related to a sense of restlessness or boredom. But now it is more about movements, routes, and channels of distribution.”

David Horvitz is a Fluxus inspired artist living in Brooklyn, NY. His work has touched on relationships, social networks, public knowledge, mail art, and collaboration. Some of his projects have taken on forms that include Wikipedia, packages, hairballs, posters, photography, fundraising, and mushroom hunting. Horvitz is an artist whose work flows seamlessly into his everyday life using the virtual sphere. His instagram feed is a wash with images of mailed drift wood, foraged mushrooms, meals, and his sometimes interspecies collaborator, his cat.
Fritz Haeg
“Art can happen anywhere, even at the core of your daily life.”

Gardener. Dancer. Artist. Architect. Teacher. Fritz Haeg’s work has included edible gardens, public dances, educational environments, animal architecture, domestic gatherings, urban parades, temporary encampments, documentary videos, publications, exhibitions, websites, and occasionally buildings for people. Recent projects include Edible Estates – an international series of public domestic edible gardens
column2: Animal Estates – a housing initiative for native wildlife in cities
column3: Sundown Schoolhouse – an itinerant educational program, which evolved out of the Sundown Salon gatherings at his geodesic home base in the hills of Los Angeles, and the new traveling project series of Domestic Integrities.

column1: J. Morgan Puett
“Being is really my practice.”
Morgan Puett is an interdisciplinary artist who “curates” her refrigerator. She looks at everyday domesticity as a potent site of creativity and education.

She is an artist, cultural producer, fashion designer, and Co-founder and Director of Mildred’s Lane Historical Society and Museum. Mildred’s Lane is a 92–acre social practice mecca situated in rural Pennsylvania, designed to collectively create and discuss new pedagogical models of being in the world with regards to the environment, systems of labor, forms of dwelling, ethics, and sociality. Mildred’s Lane is a long-term, collaborative project that promotes living as a creative research practice through a revolving cast of residents, fellows, visiting artists, scholars, and social practitioners.
Ben Kinmont
“Sometimes a nicer sculpture is making a living for your family.”

Ben Kinmont is an artist, publisher, and antiquarian bookseller. Kinmont's work is based in real-time exchanges such as meals, conversations, and gestures. In 1996 he began his publishing project, Antinomian Press, publishing material, often distributed for free. Kinmont also has an ongoing antiquarian bookselling business, begun in 1998, that specializes in books and manuscripts about domestic economy and food.
Mierle Laderman Ukeles
“That is what maintenance is, trying to listen to the hum of living. A feeling of being alive, breath to breath.”
Mierle Laderman Ukeles is an artist whose work is about maintenance, relationships, and care. She looks at the overlooked, the garbage, the daily chores, the workers.

Since 1970 she has been the unsalaried artist-in-residence for New York City's Sanitation Department where she builds and orchestrates major public projects that explore the social and ecological issues of waste management.
Risks and challenges:
One risk of the project is that I am not releasing this book through an academic press. However I am choosing to see this as an opportunity.
Most, if not all academic presses operate on model that does not compensate their contributors.
I believe that all participants need to be compensated for their work and I am looking for support from the Kickstarter community who believe both in this project and in fair wages for work.
FAQ:
Question: What if my address changes before the book is released?
Answer: Before any shipments are made we will verify the address in case of change.",3.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Portland, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/i-m-going-to-live-the-life-i-sing-about-in-my-song/pica

column21: >Three young artists will bring an innovative new approach in photographic printmaking to the International Printmaking Conference in San Francisco!

> In 2013, we (Liz Bannish and Stephanie Gaumond) began a research project into a safe, cheap photographic etching process as interns at Zea Mays Printmaking in Florence, MA. This work seemed so promising that we submitted a proposal to demonstrate it to printmakers from all over the world at the Southern Graphics Council International Printmaking Conference in San Francisco in March 2014. The proposal was accepted and we are now raising the needed funds to get to San Francisco. The conference is a massive networking and resource sharing opportunity for printmakers worldwide.

> Zea Mays Printmaking Director Liz Chalfin leads research projects with interns each half-year, testing developments in less-toxic and non-toxic printmaking. Since March 2013, continuous experiments by current intern Cathe Janke have shown incredible potential for a hobbyist circuit board film, called Press-n-Peel PBC Blue, to provide an alternative to standard photo-based etching techniques, completely excluding the need for UV tables and harmful emulsions. The demonstration, entitled “Iron-On Photo Intaglio,” would demonstrate the results of such experiments and possibilities of this material as a new tool for printmakers at SGC San Francisco.

> This year’s Conference theme is “Bridges,” stressing the relationship between art and science, tradition and innovation. Like so many other printmaking techniques, inspiration for ""Photo-Intaglio"" was drawn from processes outside of the world of fine art. A bridge is created between art and technology, one that has become very familiar today. “Iron-On Photo Intaglio” takes a literal approach to this concept. As printmaking itself had been the missing link between art, science, and accessibility, so too is this process. It provides an attainable alternative to expensive equipment needed for usual photographic printing. PCB Blue also has the added bonus of being able to be manipulated through other printmaking processes. Connecting photographic intaglio with other methods like drypoint and monotype, it affords a flexibility other photo based techniques cannot. Bannish and Gaumond, with support from members of Zea Mays Printmaking studio, are the original testers of the film and submitters of the project proposal to the SGC. Tests continue under the supervision of fall intern Cathe Janke, and their results grow more superb by the day.

> By bringing this research to SGC San Francisco in 2014, we hope to both showcase the exciting aspects of the film, as well as start a discussion about its future through the networking opportunities SGC will no doubt offer. Zea Mays Printmaking hopes to pass on their research about this exciting new material so that others may explore it for themselves.
> Indiegogo funds will help offset the costs of getting the three of us to attend the conference, and bring our research materials to San Francisco and back!
>The gifts for supporters include one-of-a-kind prints, books of print compilations, tutorials of our project, and public recognition during our demonstration.

Summary

Hello everyone! On behalf of some of the members of PC '13, we have decided to commission Mike Savage to paint a picture of KU's Kappa Alpha Theta. For those of you who may be unfamiliar with Mike Savage, he is an iconic painter in the Kansas City area that specializes in many of Kansas City's, as well as KU's, landmarks. Below, we have included some examples of Savage's paintings of Greek houses on KU's campus. We hope that with this fundraiser we can have a beautiful painting of the Theta house!
KU Kappa Kappa Gamma
KU Phi Kappa Psi
KU Pi Beta Phi
If you would like to see more of Mike's work please check out his website.

As recent graduates we would love to have a way to keep Theta with us, even though we have left Lawrence. We believe that PC' 13 can't possibly be the only ones who hold Theta so near and dear to our hearts, so we started this campaign in order to raise funds for a Mike Savage Kappa Alpha Theta painting.

This online campaign is to raise $1,050.00. This total amount includes the creation of the original painting which is priced at $1000.00 (24 x 30 canvas and frame) and a $50.00 fee for the use of this website. Once the painting is completed (expected date around November 1st) it will be made into prints that can be ordered through Mike's gallery, just like all of his other work. The prints are very reasonably priced and come in a variety of sizes. We plan to donate the original framed painting to the Theta house in Lawrence, KS.

The rough sketch of the painting is below. Keep in mind that we plan to make further adjustments because there are minor things we would like to change, such as removing the large ""KAO"" and adding the yard and circle drive. However, we wanted to ensure that we would have enough money for the completion of the painting before moving further along in the process.

This campaign will run for 60 days. Without raising this money, we will not be able to create this image! If we do not receive the full $1,050.00 in 60 days, all of the money that has been donated will be returned to the credit cards you used to make the donation. Most major credit cards are taken. Remember, your donation to this site is just for the original painting and then around mid-November you can order prints through Mike Savage's website.
Indiegogo is a very secure site for donations
column2: many people use it for a variety of different campaigns. If you do not feel comfortable donating through this website please contact Elissa Bernstein at bernsteinelissa@yahoo.com, and we can set something up so that you are still able to donate.

column1: We would appreciate the support of the collegians, alumni, and family of KU Kappa Alpha Theta members, as this is not just a painting to be a hung on a wall, but a way to cherish all the memories that took place in this house.
Any questions? Please email Elissa Bernstein at bernsteinelissa@yahoo.com or Meghan Doherty at Mdoherty11@ku.edu. We would like to thank you in advance for your donation!
Theta love and ours,

PC '13

About

My name is Tara, I'm a photographer and graphic designer in the UK. I work full time as a graphic designer during the week and only get time to organise and do photoshoots in the evenings and at weekends.

At the beginning of 2013 my Aunt was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. My family has been affected in many ways through the generations: OCD, Dementia, Schizophrenia, Manic Depression, and now Parkinson's. I decided after hearing the news of my Aunt's condition, to try and do my bit and raise some money to help towards finding better treatments and eventually, a cure.

In the last couple of months I've been organising a photoshoot of epic proportions - a full body painting marathon. Eleven models and eight makeup artists &
column2:
hair stylists are joining forces to create beautiful images to raise awareness of this horrible degenerative disease and get some donations in at the same time.


Please donate!

column1:
A lot of models and makeup artists are travelling from all over the UK to join in at this event, giving up their time and energy to create something amazing. A few people involved also have loved ones affected by Parkinson's, so this shoot means a lot to everyone.

Please give anything you can, even £1. It all helps!


Fun Perks of Donating

If you donate over a certain amount and choose to receive a 'perk', you will get a small gift from us! It's a lovely way of saying thank you and a great memory to keep.


Other Ways You Can Help

We'll have a jar to collect donations in on the day of the shoot, so if you don't feel comfortable donating on here you can give your donation to a model, makeup artist or assistant and they can bring it with them.

Most importantly - please SHARE!

Thank you ever so much, and wish us all luck!
Tara x

We Love Stompin' Tom!
We’re a non-profit group of ordinary folks, from
the land of Sudbury Saturday Night, and huge Stompin’ Tom fans.  Our goal is simple:  <b>We
want to honour Stompin’ Tom Connors with a life-sized, bronze statue in
downtown Sudbury, Ontario, near arts and hockey venues.
And we hope to say that Canadians participated, from every city and town in Canada, coast
to coast!
We’ve already raised more than
20% of our $50,000 goal locally, and we’re going to have some pretty lively
fundraisers here in Sudbury.  But,
Stompin’ Tom belonged to all of Canada.
He sang OUR stories, from the legend of Big Joe Mufferaw to the devotion
of Hockey Moms across the land. He was
authentic and raw, and we miss this true Canadian voice.
A local sculptor, Tyler Fauvelle (see photo, above), has finished sculpting the life-sized artwork in clay. It's now at the foundry, for casting in bronze.
join in...When the sculpture’s unveiled, we want to say: Hello there!  And
thanks to people from
column3:
> city and town in Canada!


How do we thank you for your contribution?

column1: We’ve
designed a <b>special logo, <span>exclusively for buttons,
T-shirts and plaques, so that you can proudly show you participated in
paying tribute to Tom...Show off  your
T-shirt at the next sporting event or concert you go to!  Get your office buddies together, and earn a
plaque for the coffee room...If your Mom spent years taking you to hockey and
cheering for you in a cold arena, play the Hockey Mom song for her, and give
her a button!  (And a hug!)
If you
send $10, we’ll know you’re thinking of Stompin’ Tom, and we promise to tip a
hat to his statue in your honour. (There’ll be a photo on our Facebook page.)
For
something really special...The artist, Tyler
Fauvelle, created a <b>limited edition art
resin sculpture exclusively for this project.  Tyler says that the artwork, called “Dear
Canada”, is inspired by the final letter Tom Connors wrote to his fans.  The edition is limited to 45, and is not for
sale.  We’re sending them as a “thank
you” to those who contribute at least $500 ($425 for you Early Birds) to this
commemoration.  Each piece is numbered,
and comes with a commemoration certificate of authenticity, signed by the
artist.  “Dear Canada” measures 8” high,
and is hand-finished in verdigris.
“Stompin’ Tom’s music was inspired by the
vivid beauty of our country, and he sang the extraordinary stories of ordinary
people. The guitar stock in the sculpture bends toward the flames of the maple
leaf, forming a heart-space, and representing the passion of the patriotic
torch Tom held before our eyes, and hoped we would keep ablaze.  Tom Connors loved Canada, and it’s as simple
– and as complicated – as that.  The
verdigris finish suggests legacy, and a certain roughness, because Tom’s road
was rarely easy<span>. His famous hat is represented
here, of course, resting by the guitar – close to the music, where it belongs.”
Tyler Fauvelle
Tyler
is donating thirty-five of the limited edition to this Indiegogo campaign, and
encourages all of Stompin’ Tom’s friends to help with this tribute – please
pass the word along!
about!
to the unveiling! No kidding – check out the
column3: > packages.  We’d be so glad to see you, friends.

column1: Are you not too far from Sudbury, and do you like a
great party? Well, for $200 ($175 for the Early Birds), you get a special
invitation to the unveiling, and to the Sudbury Saturday Night unveiling party
at the famous Townehouse here in Sudbury.
If you want us to, we’ll introduce you at the party, and present you
with a T-shirt and a button. (We’re working out the details, but you’ll have at
least one month’s notice.)
Thank you for being a part of Tom’s “Stompin’ Ground”!
Other Ways You Can Help
<span>Help us spread the word - follow us, like us and

share us.

twitter.com/stompinstatue
facebook.com/stompinstatue

Also
if you want to get involved in other ways, we’d be so glad to hear from
you!  Please drop us a line at stompintomcommemorative@gmail.com

Thank you for being a part of Tom’s “Stompin’ Ground”!

if you want to get involved in other ways, we’d be so glad to hear from

Our Story So Far

Why do we create monsters?

Isn't living on a tiny speck of dust, in a universe of infinite chaos and destruction frightening enough? 

Perhaps that is the reason. Perhaps the reality of our existence is so much harder to take.

We want to explore the darkness that sits inside our heads and do it in such a manner that everyone who visits us is, in no small part, forever altered by the experience. We want people to leave our establishment with a head full of disturbing ideas and notions.

We want to create London's first serious horror museum. 

Based in London's East End, the Museum of Horror will be weird, disturbing, informative, horrifying, educational and entertaining. Mixing fact, fantasy, art and artifice, we want to take our visitors on a very unusual journey. 

To start with, we will explore 7 popular horror themes, with the following 7 main exhibits (all artwork is the copyright of the Museum of Horror).
<td>

""A corner of a tented field hospital showing the aftermath of a zombie attack. Blood stained polythene sheeting, BIO-HAZARD protection abounds. A low groaning and moaning is heard from inside a body bad. Broken, rotting fingers are clawing at the tent panels.""
<td>

""A Victorian gentlemans club, a corner wing chair. A nosferatu like figure half in shadow, eyes glowing red. A serving girl kneeling before him, he feeds. The muted tick of a grandfather clock and the sound of nourishment being obtained are all you can hear. So civilised.""
3. Werewolves
<td>
""A cage, inside a werewolf, bathed in moonlight. It is part of a very rich gentleman's private menagerie. It feeds - noisily - on the severed arm of someone who got to close.""
4. Serial Killers
<td>
""A 1970’s kitchen diner, Fred and Rose at the table, Denis Nielsen at the fridge, Christie hanging his coat up.
In the background a wireless radio lists out the names of missing people...""
5. Possession
<td>
""A childs bedroom, a boy is smiling, surrounded by distorted, mishapen toys.  An old priest is at the foot of the bed, a young one is cowering in the corner.""
6. Hell
<td>

""A demon at a turnstile, watching over everyone who enters the door way. A queue by a door that is ajar, red flickering light can be seen. A window behind the Demon shows the silhouette of  a geometrically impossible walkway with figures shuffling across it forever.""
7. Freaks of Nature / Natural Horror
<td>

""In the style of a tented a Victorian freak show, John Merrick introduces you to the freakish horrors of the natural world, including walking cancers and viruses the size of men, the effects of disfiguring diseases etc.""

We will then look to expand and add a performance area and screening room for classic and independent horror movies and short films. It is intended that the performance area will also provide writers and performance artists with a venue to share their own darkness with those curious (and brave) enough to attend.

What We Need From You &
column2:
What You Get From Us

This round of funding will help us develop and finish 7 exhibits (this incorporates modular / demountable set construction, prop acquisition, model building and GALLONS of liquid latex and other fine substances...).

No one working on the Museum of Horror, gets a salary or currently claims any expenses. Every penny / dime raised goes into turning the imagination of our curator into something that you can see and touch and that you can feel.

Our perks are designed to be different. Become part of the team or better still, become part of the experience! The face of a zombie, your name in the book of death, and lots more besides.

The Difference We Want To Make

We love horror and we take it very seriously. We believe the need to create darkness and monsters is central to what makes us human.

column1: • Horror is endlessly fascinating. Year after year, from the first images painted on a cave wall, through to the very latest multi sequel gore fest, humans have needed to create and explore darkness. For the first time, there will be a venue that takes this need seriously.
• Our desire to make this happen is backed up by 20 years in the delivery of complex projects worldwide and contribution from family members who have been involved in museum projects globally.
<li><span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >The Museum of Horror is not (and will never be) a glorified theme park attraction or haunted house venue. It will disturb, it will chill the blood, but it will always be authentic and force you to think about the very nature of humanity.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Obviously we would LOVE you to contribute financially to the Museum of Horror and get hold of one of our perks, but we also understand that you might not be able to contribute this way, however that doesn’t mean you can’t help us:
• Ask your friends, your family, fellows lovers of horror and darkness to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
• Volunteer to work on exhibits, create props, art work, marketing materials. We can't pay you a salary, but we will ensure you get plenty of good references.
• Use the Indiegogo share tools! In fact, use any share tools you like!

And that’s all there is to it.

","Our Story So FarWhy do we create monsters?Isn't living on a tiny speck of dust, in a universe of infinite chaos and destruction frightening enough? Perhaps that is the reason. Perhaps the reality of our existence is so much harder to take.We want to explore the darkness that sits inside our heads and do it in such a manner that everyone who visits us is, in no small part, forever altered by the experience. We want people to leave our establishment with a head full of disturbing ideas and notions.We want to create London's first serious horror museum. Based in London's East End, the Museum of Horror will be weird, disturbing, informative, horrifying, educational and entertaining. Mixing fact, fantasy, art and artifice, we want to take our visitors on a very unusual journey. To start with, we will explore 7 popular horror themes, with the following 7 main exhibits (all artwork is the copyright of the Museum of Horror).

A corner of a tented field hospital showing the aftermath of a zombie attack. Blood stained polythene sheeting, BIO-HAZARD protection abounds. A low groaning and moaning is heard from inside a body bad. Broken, rotting fingers are clawing at the tent panels.""

A Victorian gentlemans club, a corner wing chair. A nosferatu like figure half in shadow, eyes glowing red. A serving girl kneeling before him, he feeds. The muted tick of a grandfather clock and the sound of nourishment being obtained are all you can hear. So civilised.""
3. Werewolves
A cage, inside a werewolf, bathed in moonlight. It is part of a very rich gentleman's private menagerie. It feeds - noisily - on the severed arm of someone who got to close.""
4. Serial Killers
A 1970’s kitchen diner, Fred and Rose at the table, Denis Nielsen at the fridge, Christie hanging his coat up.
In the background a wireless radio lists out the names of missing people...""
5. Possession
A childs bedroom, a boy is smiling, surrounded by distorted, mishapen toys.  An old priest is at the foot of the bed, a young one is cowering in the corner.""
6. Hell

A demon at a turnstile, watching over everyone who enters the door way. A queue by a door that is ajar, red flickering light can be seen. A window behind the Demon shows the silhouette of  a geometrically impossible walkway with figures shuffling across it forever.""
7. Freaks of Nature / Natural Horror

In the style of a tented a Victorian freak show, John Merrick introduces you to the freakish horrors of the natural world, including walking cancers and viruses the size of men, the effects of disfiguring diseases etc.""

We will then look to expand and add a performance area and screening room for classic and independent horror movies and short films. It is intended that the performance area will also provide writers and performance artists with a venue to share their own darkness with those curious (and brave) enough to attend.What We Need From You & What You Get From UsThis round of funding will help us develop and finish 7 exhibits (this incorporates modular / demountable set construction, prop acquisition, model building and GALLONS of liquid latex and other fine substances...).No one working on the Museum of Horror, gets a salary or currently claims any expenses. Every penny / dime raised goes into turning the imagination of our curator into something that you can see and touch and that you can feel.Our perks are designed to be different. Become part of the team or better still, become part of the experience! The face of a zombie, your name in the book of death, and lots more besides.The Difference We Want To MakeWe love horror and we take it very seriously. We believe the need to create darkness and monsters is central to what makes us human.

Horror is endlessly fascinating. Year after year, from the first images painted on a cave wall, through to the very latest multi sequel gore fest, humans have needed to create and explore darkness. For the first time, there will be a venue that takes this need seriously.
Our desire to make this happen is backed up by 20 years in the delivery of complex projects worldwide and contribution from family members who have been involved in museum projects globally.

The Museum of Horror is not (and will never be) a glorified theme park attraction or haunted house venue. It will disturb, it will chill the blood, but it will always be authentic and force you to think about the very nature of humanity.

Other Ways You Can HelpObviously we would LOVE you to contribute financially to the Museum of Horror and get hold of one of our perks, but we also understand that you might not be able to contribute this way, however that doesn’t mean you can’t help us:
Ask your friends, your family, fellows lovers of horror and darkness to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Volunteer to work on exhibits, create props, art work, marketing materials. We can't pay you a salary, but we will ensure you get plenty of good references.
Use the Indiegogo share tools! In fact, use any share tools you like!
And that’s all there is to it.",7.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","London, United Kingdom",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/museum-of-horror/pica

column1: ","The story so far:

My name is Tony Plant. I am an independent, UK artist, have been for over 20 years. It's been a stretch at times but always hugely rewarding. By choice I work outside in remote and wild places, the world over, focussing attention on natural shape, colour and form. My work is a direct response to the environment in which it is placed.

The Last Tree on Earth is a creative attempt to affect change and highlight issues of sustainability and environmental impact etc by placing a trigger  (in the form of a painting) inside the viewers' home/work place. Sixteen paintings, as pictured with Andy Cummins. see below (ranging from 30cm to 1 metre square)

Every multiple of $1,001 raised will ensure another of the 16 paintings is out travelling, evoking and gathering personal stories, highlighting the importance of relationships we as individuals attach to trees in general and specific trees in particular.

The intention is for each painting to travel through a broad ranging set of individuals. This will ensure that the degree of focus within each set of response groups remains high. A number of creative groups have already been confirmed as starting points for some of the paintings. These include:
surf communities in Hawaii and Ireland
professional story tellers in schools
British Antarctic Survey Scientists
various faith groups
artists
musicians
theatre groups
outreach centres
environmentalists, NGO's
film makers
What We Need & Why
In order to keep the original idea intact we need help with practicalities. We have learnt from the last 2 months, how difficult it is to move paintings through many hands, countries and borders.

1 small 30cm painting (left) just came back to the UK from a quick test trip around the Hawaiian islands in December, where it was introduced to surfers, Buttons Kaluhiokalani, Dave Rastovitch (left) Shane Dorian to blatantly name drop but a few, however, aside from triggering some amazing responses (and featuring in a UK Magazine, left) it's journey has highlighted the problems associated with transport/movement of paintings. In order to physically move a maximum of 16 around, individually made, tough, light, simple freight boxes need to be made.
Hence this campaign, ""more cash, more miles and more time away"".

Every multiple of $1,001 will ensure another of the 16 paintings is out travelling safely. Gathering personal stories, highlighting the importance of relationships we as individuals attach to trees in general and specific trees in particular (it also ensures the painting returns for exhibition alongside the other 15 paintings)
Other Ways You Can Help
What else can I do to support the Last Tree?

If you have been convinced that this project is worth your money, please help us find more supporters. You can direct your friends, family, work colleagues or team mates to check our regular updates on Indiegogo as well as hitting our Twitter, Facebook, Tumblr or website if they would like to find out more?
Thanks for taking the time, all the best to you and yours, Tony",6.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Newquay, Cornwall, United Kingdom",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-last-tree-on-earth/pica

""History is being written by the artists while the factory worker's struggle...
column2: >what we need are gifts and connections and humanity -and the artists who create them.""  --Seth Godin,

column1: A one way ticket to New York City.  With nothing but our cameras, the little money in our pockets, and the clothes on our backs.  8 hours on the bus, we drove through the night.  Jersey City.  New York City.  Port Authority. Times Square.  The sun
was just starting to rise and it lit the streets with a warm pink glow.

Subway.   World Trade Center.  Zuccotti Park.  We had made it to Occupy Wall Street.  We spent three nights sleeping on the sidewalk, and documented every minute of action in between.  We marched the streets, met in general assembly, and made our voices heard.  As artists, and in the words of Charlie Chaplin, ""We the people have the power, the the power to
create happiness. We the people have the power to make life free and
beautiful.""

I would like to put this body of work together and display in in my hometown of Buffalo, NY.  I want to show people that, even though the movement has morphed into protests against corporate greed and politics, that it is rooted in freedom, happiness, and love for all.  All art will be printed by the artist, and all flyers and promotional materials will be hand printed and silkscreened by the artist.  No big corporations for this show!
Part of the series can be viewed here....http://www.christinalaingphotography.com/#/port...
This will happen in three steps...
1) Secure a gallery space for the show (Approx. $200)  Date and location set!  March 22-April 6, Queen City Gallery.
2) Promotional materials (Approx. $100)
3) Printing (all left over funds will go towards printing and display)
Support independent artists and filmmakers
column2: Occupy Wall Street: an artist's perspective.

column1: ","""History is being written by the artists while the factory worker's struggle...what we need are gifts and connections and humanity -and the artists who create them.""  --Seth Godin, Linchpin

create happiness. We the people have the power to make life free and
beautiful.""

I would like to put this body of work together and display in in my hometown of Buffalo, NY.  I want to show people that, even though the movement has morphed into protests against corporate greed and politics, that it is rooted in freedom, happiness, and love for all.  All art will be printed by the artist, and all flyers and promotional materials will be hand printed and silkscreened by the artist.  No big corporations for this show!

column10: >What is Kawaii Kondom? Watch the video up above!

column1: Short Summary
<div>

Kawaii Kondom is a strong proponent of sex positivity. Using themes inspired by Japanese Kawaii Anime/Chibi drawings styles, the subject of sex becomes more approachable and fun to talk about. It's important to be able to communicate with your partner(s) about what you want and what you are comfortable with when it comes to sex.

Helping fund this project will provide us the initial funds to manufacture the product and get the business started. Some of the goals include securing an online retail space to sell Kawaii Kondom as well as putting costs towards providing higher quality condoms.


What We Need &
<div>
Kawaii Kondom is still early in development as a business. We need funds to get started:
<ul>
• First production run of main series
• Backer Rewards
• Online Retail Space
• Business Licenses and Expenses
• Adding more products to the Kawaii Kondom Brand
Backer Rewards:
<div style=""text-align: center
<div>
$5 USD: Senpai will Notice You - Get your name credited on the website for backing!
<div style=""text-align: center
<div>
$5 USD + Shipping: 3 Kawaii Kondoms including a handwritten thank you note with a sketch!
<div>
$10 USD + Shipping: 8 Kawaii Kondoms including a handwritten thank you note with a sketch!
<div>
$30 USD + Shipping: 25 Kawaii Kondoms including a handwritten thank you note with a sketch!
<div style=""text-align: center
<div>
$60 USD + Shipping: All 50 Kawaii Kondoms. Get the whole collections!
<div style=""text-align: center
<div>
$60 USD + Shipping: Kawaii Apparel
<div>
$80 USD + Shipping: Original Sketch of Kawaii Kondom Card Design - You get 1 of 50 of the original drawings used to make Kawaii Kondoms!
$100 USD + Shipping: Kondom-Chan Plushie

Kawaii is the name, Sex Positivity is the game! This initial series of 50 cards for Kawaii Kondom is an introduction. These condoms open approachable dialogue about sex by turning the sleezy into cute.
Other things that Kawaii Kondom finds Kawaii:
<ul>
• Consent
• Body Positivity
• LGBTQQIAA+
• Gender Equality
• Anime is real
<h3>Risks &amp
<div>

The designs have gone through many drafts and have been finalized after much refining and revisions. Prototypes of the condom packs and cards have already been made and tested. We are trying to figure what kind of condom will be the best fit for your deck. A big goal for us is being able to customize the condom itself and try to get it to be higher quality of pleasure.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Don't worry about it. You can still help by spreading the word of Kawaii Kondom by sharing this project on social media!
*Trademark Pending

If you'd like to help ignite Burning Man 2017, with a ten foot tall Fire Vortex on the Esplanade, please consider pitching in to help us make it happen. Your donations will be used to cover the costs of the fuel needed to keep the fire vortex running every night of the burn (playa weather permitting) at Phage (4:00 and Esplanade).

 

How Does It Work?

The base of the fire vortex is a propane burner outputting 500k-750k BTU per hour, surrounded by a ring of 12 vents. Each set of four vents is hooked up to an industrial blower with enough power for up to 500 cubic feet of airflow per minute per vent - which is about as much as a big leaf blower!

The air blasted from the vents will spin the flame into a flickering vortex
column2:
big enough to be warm and bright, but small enough to gather around. 

 

How Can You Help?

We’re thrilled to put our time and talents into bringing the Fire Vortex to the playa, but need your help to cover fuel costs. 

Here’s a breakdown of the full costs of the project:

column1: • Propane: $1200
• Propane accessories (cylinders and plumbing): $700
• Firepit-style ring burner: $80
• Industrial centrifugal blowers and motors: $320
• HVAC duct parts: $200
• Custom built rails with laser cut brackets to precisely aim the vents: $250
• Fire extinguishers and other safety equipment: $100
• Perimeter railing: $150

Total: $3000

We have some funding thanks to a Phage art grant, but still have a significant portion of the expenses to cover. We've set our goal at raising enough money for our projected fuel costs, and we massively appreciate anything you want to give to help us make this happen.

 

What Do You Get?

Perks include stickers, patches, pendants and holographic booty shorts all emblazoned with the Fire Vortex logo. See our perks and their pretty digital mockups to the right for details :-)

 

What is Phage?

The Phage is a diverse consortium of 100+ scientists, engineers, and artists. Our mission is to infect the playa with science. For the past several years we have been located on the Esplanade. Some of the science outreach activities we have run include:
<li>On-playa nightly seminar series. Past topics included:<ul>
• Subterranean communication
• The geology of Black Rock Desert
• Research on love and emotion
• Defining reality through information
• The neuroscience of meditation, and much more.
• Micro-zoo. We brought an entire zoo of micro-organisms, and the microscopes to watch them here.
<li>Ask a scientist. Go on
• A giant, musical Tesla coil!
• Fun with gallium, Fresnel lenses, and liquid nitrogen.
• Experience One Joule (now you're curious).
• Suturing workshop. Learn and practice making medical sutures.

Thank You for Your Help Lighting the Flame!

Please help us spread the word about this campaign to bring the Fire Vortex to the playa!

Thank you! <
column2:
3

Brian, Helena, Matt, Dan, Aurora, Gavan, Stephen, Brendan and The Phage

column2: >~ A Love Letter to La Luna ~
column3: >Hello! I’m Lauren Ruth, Creatrix of LunaRhythms yearly planner.
column4: >I was raised in the Pacific Northwest on my family’s farm, and I’ve spent the last decade homesteading in the wild mountains of the Western United States. My lifestyle is based on the cycles and seasons of Nature, and I created this annual lunar planning tool based on my own amazing life experiences of the past ten years - tracking the fertility cycles of my own body, growing and wildcrafting food and medicine and living off-grid and out under the open sky. I needed a visual tool to help me understand how to manage my time and work with the energies of the seasons and moon phases. This planner was re-created in various forms over the years. I have experimented, explored and created my life with La Luna as my guide! LunaRhythms is the culmination of this work, and I lovingly offer her to the you in the hope that she will be of service to You and your amazing life!
column5: >LunaRhythms is an invitation to care for ourselves by paying attention to our bodies and the phases of the moon as we make our life plans.
column6: >Many of us are trying to function in a world that is out of touch with the natural cycles and seasons of life, a world that is out of touch with the Divine Feminine. We may find ourselves feeling exhausted and wondering if there is another way to be. How can we understand what it is we truly want and need when we are too busy with endless actions to pause for a moment and connect? Body awareness and Nature connection are keys to sourcing from a place of feminine power and allowing our intuition to guide us. When you support LunaRhythms, you <i><strong>support yourself &amp
column7: others in taking a deeper step into the wild landscape of your own true nature.
column8: >How can you best work with this calendar?
column9: >​~Plan your entire year at a glance
column10: >~ Bring the *magic* of La Luna into your life
column11: >~Deepen your personal connection with Mother Nature
column12: ><strong>~ Observe your body's cycles with the phases &amp
column13: signs of the Moon
column16: '>~ Plan ahead for your projects and your garden by the Moon Cycle
column17: >~ Set goals and make plans months in advance utilizing Moon Magic
column19:
>I’m hoping to raise $13,000 in honor of the 13 moons! About half of all funds raised will go towards the printing and shipping of gifts to all the generous backers of LunaRhythms. The other half of funds raised will go towards start-up costs. Here are the start-up cost estimates:

~ Graphic Design = $1,000

~ Web Design = $1,500

~ VA services = $500

~ Web Start-up Costs = $750

~ Start-up Promotion = $1,000

~ Cushion for the Unexpected = $450

~ 10% Platform &
column20:
Processing fees = $1,300

Here’s a more detailed description of these start-up costs: 

*Graphic design and web design -  I am not a Graphic Designer and this technical art form is necessary to bring LunaRhythms to life! Web Design is needed to set up a functional website and online store so I can offer LunaRhythms to those I am hoping to serve. 

*VA = Virtual Assistant - I’ve connected with a professional online assistant who can help me in setting up the online platform - there’s a lot to do and I am still learning how to do it all! I’d like to hire her for the next 2 months to help me get it all set up and this jump-start of support will help me to work with the online platform that will allow me to reach a larger audience. 

*The web start-up costs will cover expenses for web hosting, important software, domain names and start-up service fees from online e-commerce providers like amazon and paypal. 

*Start-up promotion is a budget created to help cover the costs of two goals for LunaRhythms: Half of this budget will go towards paid promotion on the web for one month. This will help me reach the people who want and need LunaRhythms the most! Getting the word out is one of the most important aspects of making this project successful in the long term - LunaRhythms must self-support as a small business for this project to continue into 2018 and beyond. The remaining portion of the promotion budget will fund an important aspect of LunaRhythms - I am working to bring together a group of 13 like-minded visionaries who I can turn to for feedback and inspiration as I continue to improve this offering, and I’d like to give them each a calendar as a thank-you for the amazing work they do and for their support of LunaRhythms!

*Cushion for the unexpected - starting a business is an adventure! I want to have a small budget for unexpected costs in case of emergency, such as printing issues or computer malfunction.

*10% platform and processing fees - IndiGoGo will cumulatively charge about 10% of all funds raised to cover payment processing fees and as a service charge for their crowdfunding platform.

Each backer will also have their name posted indefinitely on the Gratitude page of the LunaRhythms website unless they wish to remain anonymous. I will also be offering variations of my main product, the LunaRhythms Yearly Planner. There are two different sizes available, and you can order multiple copies! This calendar is made of high-quality, durable paper and is printed to perfection with a matte finish so you can write on each day of the year with any type of pencil or pen.
