","~ A Love Letter to La Luna ~Hello! I’m Lauren Ruth, Creatrix of LunaRhythms yearly planner. I was raised in the Pacific Northwest on my family’s farm, and I’ve spent the last decade homesteading in the wild mountains of the Western United States. My lifestyle is based on the cycles and seasons of Nature, and I created this annual lunar planning tool based on my own amazing life experiences of the past ten years - tracking the fertility cycles of my own body, growing and wildcrafting food and medicine and living off-grid and out under the open sky. I needed a visual tool to help me understand how to manage my time and work with the energies of the seasons and moon phases. This planner was re-created in various forms over the years. I have experimented, explored and created my life with La Luna as my guide! LunaRhythms is the culmination of this work, and I lovingly offer her to the you in the hope that she will be of service to You and your amazing life!LunaRhythms is an invitation to care for ourselves by paying attention to our bodies and the phases of the moon as we make our life plans. Many of us are trying to function in a world that is out of touch with the natural cycles and seasons of life, a world that is out of touch with the Divine Feminine. We may find ourselves feeling exhausted and wondering if there is another way to be. How can we understand what it is we truly want and need when we are too busy with endless actions to pause for a moment and connect? Body awareness and Nature connection are keys to sourcing from a place of feminine power and allowing our intuition to guide us. When you support LunaRhythms, you support yourself & others in taking a deeper step into the wild landscape of your own true nature. How can you best work with this calendar?​~Plan your entire year at a glance~ Bring the *magic* of La Luna into your life~Deepen your personal connection with Mother Nature~ Observe your body's cycles with the phases & signs of the Moon ~ Plan ahead for your projects and your garden by the Moon Cycle~ Set goals and make plans months in advance utilizing Moon MagicRequest for Funding:I’m hoping to raise $13,000 in honor of the 13 moons! About half of all funds raised will go towards the printing and shipping of gifts to all the generous backers of LunaRhythms. The other half of funds raised will go towards start-up costs. Here are the start-up cost estimates:~ Graphic Design = $1,000~ Web Design = $1,500~ VA services = $500~ Web Start-up Costs = $750~ Start-up Promotion = $1,000~ Cushion for the Unexpected = $450~ 10% Platform & Processing fees = $1,300Here’s a more detailed description of these start-up costs: *Graphic design and web design -  I am not a Graphic Designer and this technical art form is necessary to bring LunaRhythms to life! Web Design is needed to set up a functional website and online store so I can offer LunaRhythms to those I am hoping to serve. *VA = Virtual Assistant - I’ve connected with a professional online assistant who can help me in setting up the online platform - there’s a lot to do and I am still learning how to do it all! I’d like to hire her for the next 2 months to help me get it all set up and this jump-start of support will help me to work with the online platform that will allow me to reach a larger audience. *The web start-up costs will cover expenses for web hosting, important software, domain names and start-up service fees from online e-commerce providers like amazon and paypal. *Start-up promotion is a budget created to help cover the costs of two goals for LunaRhythms: Half of this budget will go towards paid promotion on the web for one month. This will help me reach the people who want and need LunaRhythms the most! Getting the word out is one of the most important aspects of making this project successful in the long term - LunaRhythms must self-support as a small business for this project to continue into 2018 and beyond. The remaining portion of the promotion budget will fund an important aspect of LunaRhythms - I am working to bring together a group of 13 like-minded visionaries who I can turn to for feedback and inspiration as I continue to improve this offering, and I’d like to give them each a calendar as a thank-you for the amazing work they do and for their support of LunaRhythms!*Cushion for the unexpected - starting a business is an adventure! I want to have a small budget for unexpected costs in case of emergency, such as printing issues or computer malfunction.*10% platform and processing fees - IndiGoGo will cumulatively charge about 10% of all funds raised to cover payment processing fees and as a service charge for their crowdfunding platform.Gifts from LunaRhythmsI have created ten different tiers for donations, meaning ten exciting opportunities to support LunaRhythms and prepare for the coming new year! Each generous backer will receive a personalized thank you email and a copy of the upcoming E-book “LunaRhythms Guide to Moon Magic & Mystery.”  This E-book may secretly be my most valuable offering, so I want to make sure all my lovely backers have access to this inspiring guide to living your life in tune with the Moon! Each backer will also have their name posted indefinitely on the Gratitude page of the LunaRhythms website unless they wish to remain anonymous. I will also be offering variations of my main product, the LunaRhythms Yearly Planner. There are two different sizes available, and you can order multiple copies! This calendar is made of high-quality, durable paper and is printed to perfection with a matte finish so you can write on each day of the year with any type of pencil or pen. Other gifts include a ceramic mug and a cotton tote bag with LunaRhythms' unique logo printed beautifully in full color. Backers in the United States can expect to receive their thank-you gifts by December 15th at the latest. If you’re not sure what to get for the women in your life this coming holiday season, rest assured that LunaRhythms offerings will make excellent gifts for the coming new year!Let’s make our dreams for 2017 shine like the light of the full moon! ~ Risks & Challenges ~ I am putting all my best energy into making LunaRhythms real, because it is so important to me. This specific design came to me in a dream, and I knew that I had to make it happen. I have spent the better part of this year working on the specific design and vision for LunaRhythms, in an attempt to bring my best offering as a gift to the women of the world - a love letter to La Luna. The greatest obstacle to making this happen is a lack of financial resources. Turns out, it takes money to make this happen! I hope to raise $13,000 in honor of the 13 moons of the year. I am working to support myself while creating LunaRhythms, and I am putting in 12 hour days, working every day of the week. My dream is to hire other women in the tech industry to help me create the online platform needed to reach the audience I am hoping to serve. If I am not able to reach my funding goal I will need to find professionals who believe in the importance of this project and are willing to work pro-bono or who can wait to get paid for their needed technical skills.If this campaign is not able to meet the funding goal of $13,000 we will still be able to fulfill all the gifts that we promise our generous backers! If we do reach our funding goal, we can make this tool available to the world. Your support is needed - please help to make this real!On the flip side, if LunaRhythms is wildly popular, I will need to call the printshop and prepare them for the large order I’ll be placing as soon as your generous donations are ready! The printing company I am working with is US based and will ship directly to backers once orders are printed. Connection With the FeminineSo many of us in today’s fast-paced high tech world feel disconnected from our own true nature, living our lives as a constant series of actions and busy beyond belief. I offer LunaRhythms to you as a tool to help plan your life within the cycles of nature and create a more sustainable lifestyle with the phases of the moon as a guiding light. When you support this project you are supporting the remembrance of the feminine in our culture, and you are supporting all women and girls as we reclaim our birthright to know our own bodies and develop a deep connection with mother nature and the moon.When in touch with our bodies and connected to Nature, we enjoy:~ a deeper sense of connection and belonging~ heightened intuition and inner knowing~ ability to predict times of ovulation and menstruation~ divine right timing as a part of life’s natural cycles~ confidence in our ability to access our creative source~ witnessing the feminine thrive in connection with La Luna! Other Ways You Can Help If you can’t contribute financially, you can still support us:~ Please help spread the word! You never know who you can reach through the world wide web of connection. Please like and share on social media!~ Stay tuned for updates! There may be LunaRhythms give-aways soon!~ Stay in touch by signing up for our mailing list - we may have exciting news or other requests for support needed to bring this project to life!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

The art community has been turned upside down by COVID-19, especially here in the Bay Area. 

Janky Barge Arts Collective, the funky community you know and love, is seeking funds to not only upgrade &
column2:
renovate the Janky Barge Art Car, but to donate 30% of this fundraiser to the Safety Net Fund. A non-profit designed to help support artists in the Bay Area during the COVID-19 crisis. 

Janky Barge has always been about the community and we keep it real with serious sweat equity and a deep commitment to the principles of Burning Man. Our motto has always been one of inclusivity - “if we’ve got the space, you’ve got the spot. Come onboard.”

And now we need your help renovating the 1995 school bus to provide a better experience to more people. And to help members in our arts community too. 

What We Need 

We are seeking $15,000 to support our renovation plans, as well as donate 30% of total raised to the Safety Net Fund. 

Renovations for the interior include:

column1: • Moving the indoor bar to create more space and better flow of traffic -$1000
• Remove back wall post to reduce injury hazard - $1000
• Extending the indoor benches to allow for more people relax inside -$1000
• Jazz up the interior decor, paint, add wall features and create groovy vibes -$500
Renovations for the exterior facelift include:
• Upgrading safety features - moving side ladder to back of bus - $2000
• Sand, paint, replace shields - $2000
• Replace back flooring and assess the structure underneath -$1000
• Custom sails for ample shade during those wicked hot cruising days $2000

Total renovation costs: 

$10,500

Fiscal donation to the Safety Net Fund:

$4500 

What happens if we don’t reach $15,000?

30% of total funds raised will still be donated to the Safety Net Fund.

Perks, Perks, Perks

Swag-ger like us! We’ve got some great perks this time around that include some super special Janky Barge branded items
• Engraved Copper plaque installed on Barge
• Wooden Janky Shield LED wall decor
• Janky Photo throw pillow
• Janky Hoodie
• Janky T Shirt

The Impact of Your Donation

Things have been great! Our community is stronger than ever, and we’ve killed it on playa the last few times we’ve gone. We’ve also been featured at big events off-playa like, The Warrior’s Parade, our famous IceBreakers white party, a kid’s cancer event, and some smaller shindigs of good ol’ booty-shakin fun. 

But to maintain greatness, we need your help! This renovation project is SO important to us because we live the passion year-round. And just like our friends at the Safety Net Fund, we believe that without building up the artist community, the vibrant fabric that makes the Bay Area so special, will dwindle and die. 

This project will not only fund the Janky Barge community to gather responsibly, create art and make magic, but also offer some financial support to the very members of our artist community who are affected by the COVID-19 crisis. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to contribute money, you can still help spread the word!

Share this fundraiser to your social channels or follow us on all platforms @thejankybarge

Thank YOU!

From the doers, artists, hooligans, dreamers, tinkerers and sh*t talkers of The Janky Barge. 

**Learn more about the Safety Net Fund here

Art can heal and uplift...

...and I hope to be able to use this campaign to give the gift of art to the VA Hospital of Buffalo as well as Hospice of Buffalo with hopes that it will provide healing, hope, and renewal of the hearts and minds of the patients, visitors, and workers.
A little story

My father, a USMC Veteran, was diagnosed with Stage Four pancreatic cancer in January of 2012. During his end of life journey, he had the chance to receive services at the VA of Buffalo as well as Hospice of Buffalo.

During those times, while he was able, my brother and I would walk around with him through out the hallways of the VA as he received medical treatment. The VA had some art prints in varying states of quality. My father enjoyed looking into these paintings and they would make him feel better, as it did to my brother and I. From prints of Edward Hopper's lighthouses or sailboats, to Monet's water littlies, these wall hangings helped uplift our spirits.

When he was transferred to Hospice of Buffalo, my brother and I would wheel him around their hallways where he enjoyed looking at many donated works, from originals in Oil and acrylic, or finger paintings from children. He enjoyed these little trips until his own personal life's journey came to an end a short time later. My brother and walked the hallways during the wee hours of the night and found our minds made at peace as we shared the enjoyment at viewing the works on display. This has made me realize not only how powerful in healing art can be.
About me

As his son, I was blessed with a talent for art and with painting. I am a painter in oils. I paint in a traditional representational fashion. I try to use my painting skills as a gift from God to capture the beauty of the places all over this great country, as well as the beauty of still lifes.

I am not a fully established professional, but I have won a few small awards for my works and people enjoy the traditional representation landscapes and still lifes that I made. I have studied art for years, majored in Art in High school, studied it in college, and have pursuit the development of my skills as a painter for all of my life. I use professional techniques, professional grade materials, principles of design, composition, color theory, and other skills &
column2: techniques to create works that speak to peoples hearts and minds.

column1: You can view some of my paintings on my Pinterest Site, or read about my art journey on my blogspot blog.

Just before my dad passed, I made this painting for him. It was from a trip he took to visit my wife and I while we were in AZ. We saw this herd of Elk up in Flagstaff including this young calf being watched over by the elders of the herd:
<h3>My Goal &amp
Here's my goal:

I have contacted both the VA Hospital of Buffalo and the Hospice of Buffalo with the intention to create a series of related paintings for each organization,including landscapes and still lifes ranging in size from 12"" x 16"" through 24"" x 30"". These paintings will be created with professional grade materials, framed, and ready for hanging and display. The themes of each will be designed intentionally to be warm, harmonious, and use colors, values, shapes, and motifs that uplift the spirit.

Through coordination with the Hospice of Buffalo and the VA of Buffalo, I intend to have them hung in common areas where the patients, families, visitors, and workers can pass by and take a moment to get lost in the paintings, refreshing their hearts and spirits.
The following list outlines the materials and related cost items to make this campaign successful:
<ul>
• $1000 for linen canvas panels, stretchers, oil paints, mediums
• $1200 for durable painting frames and hanging equipment
• $300 for containers, packaging, shipping and installation

I anticipate that creating (6) paintings will take roughly six to eight weeks, plus a short period of time for the oil paints to cure and be varnished and framed. If I'm successful in achieving the funding needed to get started, my schedule goal is to complete the works ready for hanging in May of this year.
Should this campaign raise less than the targeted amount, I will proportionally reduce the number of works given the actual amounts donated.

Should this campaign raise more than the targeted amount, then I would like to use those funds to broaden the reach to create works for the other places of healing here in Buffalo including Roswell Park Cancer Institute, Catholic Hospital, et al, where these types of paintings would provide healing and happiness.
While at this time, I do not know what the response will be, there is a hope that I will be afforded the chance to use my skills and passion as a painter to spread paintings into places that heal.
The Impact
<div>

As a ex-US Navy enlisted man, and a patriot, I believe that our Veterans deserve not only great quality of medical care at the VA, but an aesthetic experience that helps uplift and heal their spirits. I also believe that those who are on their end of life journey, including their friends &
column2: family who are supporting them,  should have the chance to view works of art that bring back happy memories of their life experiences.

column1: I have personally experienced the healing and uplifting power of art. I have seen people become calmed, their minds made at peace, the sparkle of their eyes brightened while viewing art.

As a painter, I struggle with finding a way to use my talents to spread love and compassion to others. God blessed me with this talent, and I strongly desire to be able to use this campaign to bring the healing and uplifting power of art to our veterans and our family members who are on end of life journeys. I know that I have to try and seek the resources necessary and to successfully complete this campaign with hopes and prayers that these gifts of the donations of the resources as well as the final paintings will help touch many lives at the VA Hospital of Buffalo and Hospice of Buffalo.

Your financial support is like a brush stroke embedded into each painting...a brush stroke of care, encouragement, of love, and support for those who's minds and bodies are troubled. Your financial support will help uplift and heal many people for years to come.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you've read to this point, I'd ask you to provide the support you can. If you can contribute financially towards this campaign goal, it would be a tremendous blessing. If you don't have the means to contribute financially, please spread the word and help me find others who may have the resources to help hit this campaign goal.

The other thing I would ask you to do is to visit your local VA Hospital or local Hospice. Each organization does wonderful things in providing care and support of our friends, families and communities. There are many ways you can touch the lives of our veterans, or the lives of those who are passing onward into the next life. There are many volunteer opportunities out there, and lives that can be helped and touched if you take a step forward.

God bless, and thank you in advance for your support. I will make it my passion and will dedicate myself whole-heartedly to maximizing the success of this project. There are many people who can be helped through the healing power of art. I hope to an instrument as a painter to touch as many lives as I can using the blessings of my talent.
There's so much beauty that God has placed around us in this world, from natual landscapes and beautiful gardens, to the wonderful works of art that abound.

I pray for your help in affording me use my talent in painting to bring healing and uplifting joy and happiness to others.

These paintings will be created with professional grade materials, framed, and ready for hanging and display. The themes of each will be designed intentionally to be warm, harmonious, and use colors, values, shapes, and motifs that uplift the spirit.

Through coordination with the Hospice of Buffalo and the VA of Buffalo, I intend to have them hung in common areas where the patients, families, visitors, and workers can pass by and take a moment to get lost in the paintings, refreshing their hearts and spirits.
The following list outlines the materials and related cost items to make this campaign successful:
$1000 for linen canvas panels, stretchers, oil paints, mediums
$1200 for durable painting frames and hanging equipment
$300 for containers, packaging, shipping and installation

I anticipate that creating (6) paintings will take roughly six to eight weeks, plus a short period of time for the oil paints to cure and be varnished and framed. If I'm successful in achieving the funding needed to get started, my schedule goal is to complete the works ready for hanging in May of this year.
Should this campaign raise less than the targeted amount, I will proportionally reduce the number of works given the actual amounts donated.

Should this campaign raise more than the targeted amount, then I would like to use those funds to broaden the reach to create works for the other places of healing here in Buffalo including Roswell Park Cancer Institute, Catholic Hospital, et al, where these types of paintings would provide healing and happiness.
While at this time, I do not know what the response will be, there is a hope that I will be afforded the chance to use my skills and passion as a painter to spread paintings into places that heal.
The Impact

As a ex-US Navy enlisted man, and a patriot, I believe that our Veterans deserve not only great quality of medical care at the VA, but an aesthetic experience that helps uplift and heal their spirits. I also believe that those who are on their end of life journey, including their friends & family who are supporting them,  should have the chance to view works of art that bring back happy memories of their life experiences.
I have personally experienced the healing and uplifting power of art. I have seen people become calmed, their minds made at peace, the sparkle of their eyes brightened while viewing art.

As a painter, I struggle with finding a way to use my talents to spread love and compassion to others. God blessed me with this talent, and I strongly desire to be able to use this campaign to bring the healing and uplifting power of art to our veterans and our family members who are on end of life journeys. I know that I have to try and seek the resources necessary and to successfully complete this campaign with hopes and prayers that these gifts of the donations of the resources as well as the final paintings will help touch many lives at the VA Hospital of Buffalo and Hospice of Buffalo.

Your financial support is like a brush stroke embedded into each painting...a brush stroke of care, encouragement, of love, and support for those who's minds and bodies are troubled. Your financial support will help uplift and heal many people for years to come.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you've read to this point, I'd ask you to provide the support you can. If you can contribute financially towards this campaign goal, it would be a tremendous blessing. If you don't have the means to contribute financially, please spread the word and help me find others who may have the resources to help hit this campaign goal.

The other thing I would ask you to do is to visit your local VA Hospital or local Hospice. Each organization does wonderful things in providing care and support of our friends, families and communities. There are many ways you can touch the lives of our veterans, or the lives of those who are passing onward into the next life. There are many volunteer opportunities out there, and lives that can be helped and touched if you take a step forward.

God bless, and thank you in advance for your support. I will make it my passion and will dedicate myself whole-heartedly to maximizing the success of this project. There are many people who can be helped through the healing power of art. I hope to an instrument as a painter to touch as many lives as I can using the blessings of my talent.
There's so much beauty that God has placed around us in this world, from natual landscapes and beautiful gardens, to the wonderful works of art that abound.
I pray for your help in affording me use my talent in painting to bring healing and uplifting joy and happiness to others.",1.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Buffalo, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/healing-through-art/pica

2/20/13: PROJECT GOAL CHANGE

I will donate a sculpture to AMOCA even if we don't make the $30K goal -- the size will be determined by how much funds are pledged.  In this way your contribution is guaranteed to help make a new piece of public art happen!
Hello, and thanks for visiting my FertiliTree Campaign!

I worked in the corporate world for 15 years in Industrial Design until I quit that in ‘04 to devote my life to art.  After leaving that career I traveled through Thailand and India for a year, studying meditation and yoga, and filling my creative spirit with inspiration from all the ancient art and architecture.  I returned with a desire to express fundamental truths about our human nature through my artworks.

The FertiliTree will be planted near the entrance of the museum’s new location in Pomona, just east of LA.   Pomona is the Roman goddess of fruit trees, of abundance, fruitfulness, and fertility, and so I used these themes to guide the design of the sculpture.  FertiliTree has no branches and leaves, but she’ll fulfill her purpose of bearing fruits of inspiration, wonder, and pleasure in the hearts of all who see her!
The model of the piece shown above is a rough computer sketch– the final sculpture will have far more detail, color, and nuanced expression, like the Seeds have, and my Labradorite Priestess below

The FertiliTree will be by far the largest and most ambitious project I've attempted to date.   Not only will it be a wonderful addition to the museums collection and to the city of Pomona, while giving my artistic career a major boost, but it also has the potential to make a huge difference in the world, as a model for community-based funding of public art pieces, PLUS an incredibly economic fabrication method!

Public art makes a place feel loved and cared for, transforming the cities we live in from primarily functional, utilitarian spaces to places of genuine beauty, inspiration, and joy, which the world could sure use a lot more of!

For public works, I've invented a unique process of filling the ceramic sections with concrete when the piece is installed, making it incredibly strong and resilient. With this method I’ve developed we can eventually build sculptures 50-100 ft. tall, for a fraction of the cost of other public art fabrication methods.  They can be elaborately sculpted in a 3D modelling program, giving a very wide range of creative expressions.  Plus, the available glazes give an extraordinary range of color possibilities, far more and far more durable than classic public art methods.

Antoni Gaudi used ceramic elements and mosaics in his construction of Parc Guell and many other buildings in Barcelona 100 years ago, which are just as beautiful today as they were when they were first made.  This new method I’ve developed, of filling hollow ceramic forms with concrete, is much more versatile, economical, and swift, since the form for the concrete is the ceramic itself!
<h3 class=""template asset"">
Parc Guell, one of Gaudi's masterpieces in Barcelona
PREMIUMS FOR YOUR DONATION

Here are a samples of the Seeds you’ll be able to choose for your reward.  I'll be making many more over the next few weeks, and will have quite a variety for you to select from.  I'll contact you after you've donated to choose the design you want.  The 9"" versions are $50-$100, and the 2' versions are $500-$750.  Prior to this my artworks have sold for thousands of dollars, and I'm thrilled to be able to offer people a unique piece of art at a price that many more can afford, allowing my artwork to spread out into the world much farther than it has so far!

These will be available as Full Seeds, made of two halves attached together, or Half Seeds, which be just the front side, open on the back.  Half Seeds may be hung on your wall, and both types may be displayed on your desk, a mantle, a window ledge or altar, or wherever else you'd like to place this unique piece of art.
SINGLE COLOR SEEDS OF THE FERTILITREE
$50 FOR A HALF-SEED, $75 FOR A FULL SEED
TWO COLOR SEEDS OF THE FERTILITREE
$75 FOR A HALF-SEED, $100 FOR A FULL SEED
2' SEEDS OF THE FERTILITREE
$500 FOR A SINGLE COLOR, $750 FOR TWO OR MORE COLORS
Embodied Joy sculptural wall pieces: 40"" X 24"", $2,000 pledge
<div class=""full-description"">

In addition, if you pledge $50 or above, your name will be inscribed on the trunk of the sculpture, so if you happen to stop in Pomona you can find yourself acknowledged on this extraordinary piece of art you helped to make happen!

Please join me in bringing the FertiliTree to life!!  Also, it would be massively helpful if you would share this project with just a few other people.  Please forward this to some art lovers in your life -- this will spread the word far farther than I could hope to do alone.
Thank you all SO MUCH for supporting my creative passions, and for contributing to the beautification of our World.
PROJECT GOALS:

- Fund the complete construction and installation of FertiliTree, at 15’
- Fund the crafting and shipping of all rewards to donors
- Help establish a model for community-based, grass-roots funding of public art pieces
- Create a monumental public sculpture using this revolutionary fabrication technique to demonstrate it’s potential and possibilities
- Disseminate both the funding model and the technique out into the world so that far more artists can make creative use of them to support their art and their lives.
- Inspire and support the creation of many more public art pieces.
- Spread my art into the lives of many more people.
- Support my creative efforts, both directly thru Indiegogo funding, and through developing opportunities to create many more and much larger sculptures.

Short Summary

I am an artist who has been teaching art and photography in northern Rhode Island for the more than 20 years. During that time four of my students have been lost to gun violence. The One Gun Gone project is a positive professional art making , marketing exercise and community engagement that was developed in response to these experiences.

One Gun Gone is a multidisciplinary anti gun violence art project supported by students from underserved neighborhoods in urban RI. Our goal has been to take one gun off the streets, make art from it and then sell that art to fund a gun buy back. We have made the art, now we are working to sell it to fund our police sanctioned gun buy back.
What You Get

The ideas for One Gun Gone sculptures have come from thoughtful reflection on what materials we use and what those materials say about gun violence. Each of our four sculptural types started as ideas and then through trial and error became statements against gun violence in their own rite.
The transparent glass used in One Gun Gone's Glass Gun Sculptures reminds us that life is fragile.
Our Pencil Gun Sculpture reminds us (hopefully) that education is a way out of a life that has gun violence in it.
Our Crayon Gun Sculpture  reminds us that many children (crayons are primarily a child's art medium) are learning about gun violence too early in their lives.

Our fully functioning Candle Gun Sculpture reflects on the votive candles that are often used in roadside shrines erected when someone is killed by gun violence. We wanted to make a candle that reflected why people were being mourned in the first place.
Our One Gun Gone T-Shirt was designed by OGG students and designers from NAIL communications. It was hand silk screened by OGG students.

Our One Gun Gone Poster was was printed and collaboratively designed by DWRI Letter Press in Providence RI. This is a limited edition of 250 die cut, letter pressed posters suitable for framing. Students and lead artist Scott Lapham have signed the back of each poster.
The Impact

The One Gun Gone project is not only an art and marketing project. It is also a citizenship project. By this I am not referring to the legal definition of citizenship, but instead the difference between a resident and an engaged citizen. Before the One Gun Gone project many students knew they didn't like gun violence in their communities but they also didn't see a way to raise their voice against it. The One Gun Gone project has helped form that voice. This project is working to change inaction to action. This project is a lesson to all the young people participating in it. This lesson says that if you are passionate about change, you can work with the skill sets you have to make a difference in your community. It says that you can step out of your comfort zone and collaborate with others who have skill sets different than yours. And that in life, you sometimes need to.

I have seen the difference real world public art projects have had with my teenage students. After seeing a large project through to completion their perceptions of what they think is possible in their own lives is changed for the better . Our ""Moving Bus"" project took photographic portraits of public transportation riders and used those portraits to create a RI Public Transportation Authority bus wrapped with the positive images of its riders. The response to the finished project was overwhelmingly positive but the road to finishing the project was not easy. Students witnessed in real time the technical, financial and bureaucratic challenges in that project becoming a reality. They also witnessed that perseverance and teamwork among many different stake holders brought the project to fruition. These are some of the less tangible benefits that supporting the One Gun Gone project encourages.
<h3>Risks &amp

The One Gun Gone project has many, many people to thank. We are honored that Mass College of Art and Design, NAIL communications, New Urban Arts, The RI State Police, The Providence Police Dept, RI Council for the Arts, The Dept of Arts, Culture and Tourism of the City of Providence and others have supported our efforts through financial donation, access to facilities and dialog.

Our challenge now is selling our artwork to raise the money for our goal of funding a gun buy back. Every step in this long process has been a leap of faith. Each organization we have partnered with did not have to support us and we did not know if they would. We are proud of the art work we have made and are now showing it to large audience for the first time this Fall. Selling our artworks is now our next leap of faith. As you learn more about the One Gun Gone project we hope that you will partner with us too by purchasing our artwork. You can also support this project by sharing it. The more people that see the One Gun Gone project the more opportunity we have of reaching our goal.

THE FLOURISH PROJECT
Using video to enhance patient well-being

Flourish is part of Air Arts Autumn/ Winter season of exhibitions for Royal Derby Hospital. Ten regional artists were challenged to create a piece of work for the exhibition, being asked to explore the notion of flourish, responding with a piece that would be aimed towards the benefit of patients at Royal Derby Hospital.
Air Arts

Started in 2006, Air Arts’ mission was to create a well being program enhancing the experience of all hospital patients, visitors and staff that is fully embedded in the culture of the hospital, devised in partnership and with demonstrable benefits.

The Air Arts programme will work in partnership to support individual’s experiences and their ability to travel through an often unfamiliar and intimidating environment. The performance and exhibitions arts programme will provide memorable beacons for navigation and a welcoming journey through the hospital. Offering visitors visual clues as to the care and quality of experience they can expect to receive, through stimulating exhibition and transformational performance.

The arts programme offers access to experience and engagement for patients beyond clinical care supporting mood, well being and community engagement. The arts is a tool for sharing and collecting information, delivered in partnership with clinical staff it can also be a method for engaging patients more deeply in activity for therapeutic benefit.

“We are so pleased to be taking our first steps in to exhibiting film work at the hospital with Jason and his team. Their sensitivity to the environment, commitment to the cause and bravery to take on this challenge is inspiring.”

“We have been speaking with Jason for some time as to how his unique approach to film could benefit the patient experience at Derby Hospitals. The decision to show the work on screens in a series of pop up locations all over the hospital will allow the greatest possible access to the work for all sorts of patients and visitors. From the fracture clinic and X-ray to cancer services and clinical measurement thousands of visitors will get opportunity to see the work each day it is shown.”
Juliet Cooper – Air Arts Co-Ordinator
MY VISION – THE SUPERNOVA

For me, film and most art is all about escapism. Escapism into a world created by the individual or group of artists. Whether that be through film, music, performance or a combination of many, the main goal must be to create something that transports the viewer from their day to day surroundings to a place of beauty, light and visual poetry.

Within this project I am looking to reflect upon my influence from a Supernova, which is the explosion of a dying star and the creation of a nebula. The amazing colour, depth and vibrancy created within these nebula's is what I will be trying to re-create, following the narrative of reality. Although there will be no spoken words, characters representing different chemicals and reactions will take us through the journey of the star and how it creates new life.

Another of my passions is dance. I love the immersive quality that many dance styles can have, and that you can get lost within the movement of another. Renowned professional performers from Deda will be using a variety of different styles to portray their character. From ballet to contemporary, each style will be specifically designed around the characteristics they are trying to portray.
Music will be composed especially for this piece, adding to the epic, dramatic and powerful nature of the journey.
I aim to transport the viewer to a place where they can witness this natural phenomenon, escaping from their own busy narrative to a place of beauty and relaxation.
Synopsis
Power, passion, attraction, the evolution and growth of movement
column2: that is what flourish will explore.  A journey will be taken by our performers, developing on their animalistic and natural emotions, along with the depth and texture of their surroundings. They will reflect upon one of the most simple yet powerful flourishes, the explosion of a star to the creation of a nebula.

column1: Within a warmth of colour, light and movement, the path of this piece will take influence from the beauty of reality and combine to create something that will move worlds.
THE CREW
Director
Jason Elberts - http://www.youtube.com/JASONELBERTS
Production Assistants
Becky Clayden, Matt Gilooly &
Dance Company
Residents at Derby’s Deda, Adaire to Dance - http://www.adairetodance.co.uk
Photographers
Ewan Mathers - http://www.ewanmathers.com
Michelle Papka -
Alyson Jackson -
Make Up Artists
Lizzie Mazza - https://www.facebook.com/LizzieMazzaFreelanceMa...
Natalie Weetman -
Farah Akhtar -
Costume Designer
Harriet Kemp - http://harrietjade.carbonmade.com
Visual Artists
Fi Burke - http://www.fiburke.com
(And looking for more)
WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?
-       Filming Equipment – Lights, cameras, lens’, glide cam, track, jib arm etc.
-       Project equipment – Powdered paint, inks, smoke machines, set building materials, flares, dry ice etc.
-       Crew materials – Materials to make the costumes, make up, body paint.
-       Catering for shoot – So the crew can be fuelled on more than just crisps.
OUR BUDGETARY GOALS

I love the idea that thought provoking, beautiful and high quality films can be made by people from any background, whatever the budget. Myself and the crew have great experience in making every penny count, and in this project especially every penny will be accounted for, whether that be for equipment, skills or coffee to keep us going, we will be stretching the budget as far as we can to produce something equivalent to the standard of a budget ten times what we are aiming for.
Our minimum goal we must reach to make this film possible is £6,000
This is just enough to cover the costs for basic equipment hire, general expenses and getting most of the crew to “do me a favour”.
Our extended goal is £9,000

This will allow us to spend more time developing the idea, which includes hiring Quad’s Chocolate Factory. Having access to this space will give us a multitude of scope for the project to grow but also for all artists involved, as they will gain access to the space along with myself.
Our optimum goal is £12,000

Cinema quality equipment, all the space we need and room to experiment and develop the idea so that all artists can contribute fully to it’s professional quality and effectiveness as a tool for health care.
Our dream goal is £15,000

Not only will we be able to achieve all of the above, but this added budget will enable the project to be developed into the future with Air Arts and other national health care organisations. The use of this piece as a tool for engagement toward well being for many thousands of patients is a dream. This goal will enable us to begin that journey.
HOW YOU CAN HELP JASON ELBERTS FLOURISH
Donating
You can contribute to our project.
Every penny we raise through this indiegogo page will be seen up on the screen. What it will enable us to achieve far beyond what myself and the crew could produce with our time alone.
We are being strongly helped by Royal Derby Hospital &
column2: Evolve who have invested their time and resources into getting this project to the next level, but we need your help to take it further.

column1: Donating to this project will not only help local artists reach new heights within their careers, local students gain valuable work experience and myself fulfill a dream project, but most importantly will aid in the development of using video to enhance patient well-being.
Sharing
You can tell everyone about our project.
If you can’t help us out financially that’s ok. But it would be great if you could spare a few seconds of your time to share our page with as many as you can.

Share the project on Facebook,  email contact, indiegogo share tools, networking events or just yelling out in public! Also follow us on Twitter, Facebook, and our blog for constant updates and developments during the project.
WHAT WE WILL GIVE IN RETURN

We have spent much deliberation in producing a creative and diverse range of incentives. Ranging from a few quid to a few thousand, we are offering many different skill masterclasses, professional services and beautiful local artwork.

Although we will be extremely busy during the campaign, we will make time for any sponsors who are in need of help/ guidance on any professional they have brought, whether that be through chatting over the phone or meeting for a coffee.
We are open to any ideas, questions &
column2: suggestions towards the project. You can tweet, facebook or email us via the links below with

column1:
All of our sponsors will get direct notifications on all project updates and offers that will be available.

","THE FLOURISH PROJECT
Using video to enhance patient well-being

Flourish is part of Air Arts Autumn/ Winter season of exhibitions for Royal Derby Hospital. Ten regional artists were challenged to create a piece of work for the exhibition, being asked to explore the notion of flourish, responding with a piece that would be aimed towards the benefit of patients at Royal Derby Hospital.
Air Arts

Started in 2006, Air Arts’ mission was to create a well being program enhancing the experience of all hospital patients, visitors and staff that is fully embedded in the culture of the hospital, devised in partnership and with demonstrable benefits.

The Air Arts programme will work in partnership to support individual’s experiences and their ability to travel through an often unfamiliar and intimidating environment. The performance and exhibitions arts programme will provide memorable beacons for navigation and a welcoming journey through the hospital. Offering visitors visual clues as to the care and quality of experience they can expect to receive, through stimulating exhibition and transformational performance.

The arts programme offers access to experience and engagement for patients beyond clinical care supporting mood, well being and community engagement. The arts is a tool for sharing and collecting information, delivered in partnership with clinical staff it can also be a method for engaging patients more deeply in activity for therapeutic benefit.

“We are so pleased to be taking our first steps in to exhibiting film work at the hospital with Jason and his team. Their sensitivity to the environment, commitment to the cause and bravery to take on this challenge is inspiring.”

“We have been speaking with Jason for some time as to how his unique approach to film could benefit the patient experience at Derby Hospitals. The decision to show the work on screens in a series of pop up locations all over the hospital will allow the greatest possible access to the work for all sorts of patients and visitors. From the fracture clinic and X-ray to cancer services and clinical measurement thousands of visitors will get opportunity to see the work each day it is shown.”
Juliet Cooper – Air Arts Co-Ordinator
MY VISION – THE SUPERNOVA

For me, film and most art is all about escapism. Escapism into a world created by the individual or group of artists. Whether that be through film, music, performance or a combination of many, the main goal must be to create something that transports the viewer from their day to day surroundings to a place of beauty, light and visual poetry.

Within this project I am looking to reflect upon my influence from a Supernova, which is the explosion of a dying star and the creation of a nebula. The amazing colour, depth and vibrancy created within these nebula's is what I will be trying to re-create, following the narrative of reality. Although there will be no spoken words, characters representing different chemicals and reactions will take us through the journey of the star and how it creates new life.

Another of my passions is dance. I love the immersive quality that many dance styles can have, and that you can get lost within the movement of another. Renowned professional performers from Deda will be using a variety of different styles to portray their character. From ballet to contemporary, each style will be specifically designed around the characteristics they are trying to portray.
Music will be composed especially for this piece, adding to the epic, dramatic and powerful nature of the journey.
I aim to transport the viewer to a place where they can witness this natural phenomenon, escaping from their own busy narrative to a place of beauty and relaxation.
Synopsis
Power, passion, attraction, the evolution and growth of movement
column2: that is what flourish will explore.  A journey will be taken by our performers, developing on their animalistic and natural emotions, along with the depth and texture of their surroundings. They will reflect upon one of the most simple yet powerful flourishes, the explosion of a star to the creation of a nebula.

column1: Within a warmth of colour, light and movement, the path of this piece will take influence from the beauty of reality and combine to create something that will move worlds.
THE CREW
Director
Jason Elberts - http://www.youtube.com/JASONELBERTS
Production Assistants
Becky Clayden, Matt Gilooly & Brett Turner - http://www.jetproductions.co.uk
Dance Company
Residents at Derby’s Deda, Adaire to Dance - http://www.adairetodance.co.uk
Photographers
Ewan Mathers - http://www.ewanmathers.com
Michelle Papka -
Alyson Jackson -
Make Up Artists
Lizzie Mazza - https://www.facebook.com/LizzieMazzaFreelanceMa...
Natalie Weetman -
Farah Akhtar -
Costume Designer
Harriet Kemp - http://harrietjade.carbonmade.com
Visual Artists
Fi Burke - http://www.fiburke.com
(And looking for more)
WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?
-       Filming Equipment – Lights, cameras, lens’, glide cam, track, jib arm etc.
-       Project equipment – Powdered paint, inks, smoke machines, set building materials, flares, dry ice etc.
-       Crew materials – Materials to make the costumes, make up, body paint.
-       Catering for shoot – So the crew can be fuelled on more than just crisps.
OUR BUDGETARY GOALS

I love the idea that thought provoking, beautiful and high quality films can be made by people from any background, whatever the budget. Myself and the crew have great experience in making every penny count, and in this project especially every penny will be accounted for, whether that be for equipment, skills or coffee to keep us going, we will be stretching the budget as far as we can to produce something equivalent to the standard of a budget ten times what we are aiming for.
Our minimum goal we must reach to make this film possible is £6,000
This is just enough to cover the costs for basic equipment hire, general expenses and getting most of the crew to “do me a favour”.
Our extended goal is £9,000

This will allow us to spend more time developing the idea, which includes hiring Quad’s Chocolate Factory. Having access to this space will give us a multitude of scope for the project to grow but also for all artists involved, as they will gain access to the space along with myself.
Our optimum goal is £12,000

Cinema quality equipment, all the space we need and room to experiment and develop the idea so that all artists can contribute fully to it’s professional quality and effectiveness as a tool for health care.
Our dream goal is £15,000

Not only will we be able to achieve all of the above, but this added budget will enable the project to be developed into the future with Air Arts and other national health care organisations. The use of this piece as a tool for engagement toward well being for many thousands of patients is a dream. This goal will enable us to begin that journey.
HOW YOU CAN HELP JASON ELBERTS FLOURISH
Donating
You can contribute to our project.
Every penny we raise through this indiegogo page will be seen up on the screen. What it will enable us to achieve far beyond what myself and the crew could produce with our time alone.
We are being strongly helped by Royal Derby Hospital & Evolve who have invested their time and resources into getting this project to the next level, but we need your help to take it further.

Donating to this project will not only help local artists reach new heights within their careers, local students gain valuable work experience and myself fulfill a dream project, but most importantly will aid in the development of using video to enhance patient well-being.
Sharing
You can tell everyone about our project.
If you can’t help us out financially that’s ok. But it would be great if you could spare a few seconds of your time to share our page with as many as you can.

Share the project on Facebook,  email contact, indiegogo share tools, networking events or just yelling out in public! Also follow us on Twitter, Facebook, and our blog for constant updates and developments during the project.
WHAT WE WILL GIVE IN RETURN

We have spent much deliberation in producing a creative and diverse range of incentives. Ranging from a few quid to a few thousand, we are offering many different skill masterclasses, professional services and beautiful local artwork.

Although we will be extremely busy during the campaign, we will make time for any sponsors who are in need of help/ guidance on any professional they have brought, whether that be through chatting over the phone or meeting for a coffee.
We are open to any ideas, questions & suggestions towards the project. You can tweet, facebook or email us via the links below with
All of our sponsors will get direct notifications on all project updates and offers that will be available.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

About me:

Many of you know me well. My name is Alex Perkinson and I am an artist, educator, waitress, tutu-maker, and now, art therapist. I was recently accepted to a volunteer program in Chiang Mai, Thailand working with the organization Cultural Canvas Thailand/Art Relief International. I just graduated from Pratt Institute with my Master’s degree in Art Therapy and Creativity Development and I couldn’t be more excited about this opportunity to apply my knowledge and training in a new, distant, and culturally rich city.
About the Project/Trip:

My work in Thailand will be an advancement of my art therapy training. The organization that I am volunteering with, Cultural Canvas Thailand/Art Relief International, provides art lessons and art therapy sessions to organizations in Thailand serving individuals with HIV/AIDS, refugees, impoverished ethnic minorities, and sex workers.
More about Cultural Canvas Thailand:

Cultural Canvas Thailand was established in 2007 by a group of ambitious young women with backgrounds in the arts, community development, and social service. These four women fell in love with the county during their travels but also recognized a strong need for increased awareness and volunteer support of the current social issues facing Chiang Mai, Thailand. According to the Cultural Canvas Thailand website,

“We [CCT] promote equality, community interaction, and social change through artistic outreach and volunteer services in conjunction with local organizations. CCT and our partner organizations focus on education and assistance in the following areas:
<ul>
• Teaching English in Rural Schools
• Cerebral Palsy Assistance Program
• Burmese/Migrant Education Program
• Assisting At Risk Populations and Victims of Human Trafficking
• Hill Tribe Assistance Program
• Single Mothers' Empowerment and Education Program
• MSM and HIV/AIDS Outreach and Education Program
• Environmental Protection Program
• Art Relief International Volunteer Program
More about the Art Relief International Volunteer Program:
The specific program that I will be volunteering with is called Art Relief International.

“Art Relief International is an artistic outreach organization that works with a wide range of social groups and humanitarian organizations in Chiang Mai. It was created by Cultural Canvas Thailand to approach volunteerism through a creative lens.”

“Art Relief International provides a VOICE for individuals by exploring various creative means, including visual, performance and experimental arts. We believe that art is a powerful tool for change. Our mission for Art Relief International is to promote expression and cultivate the creativity that lies inside each individual. We use art to create an atmosphere of inclusion and belonging where often there is none. Art is used as a catalyst for releasing and challenging personal and societal stresses whilst encouraging cultural changes and awareness."" (http://culturalcanvas.com)
Why I need your support:

Art Relief International is a volunteer program therefore I will not be receiving any financial support during my three-month placement in Chiang Mai. I will also need to fund my flight to and from Chiang Mai, visa, and vaccinations independently. As is the case with most volunteer-based organizations, there are also fees associated with the program. These fees cover the cost of registration, a donation to the host organization, pre-trip orientation materials, travel health insurance, in-country orientation and city tour, in-country transportation to and from placement, accommodation, food, Thai language training, in-country staff support, and 24-hour emergency assistance.

I will be working VERY HARD myself over the next three months to save up for this trip but I would truly appreciate your help in making this possible. Although this campaign is designed for monetary contributions, for those who are unable to give, moral support is also GLADY ACCEPTED.
Further Reading:
For more information on Cultural Canvas Thailand/Art Relief International, please check out the following links or feel free to e-mail me any questions.
http://www.culturalcanvas.com/
https://www.facebook.com/CCT.ARI
http://www.artrelief.net/

http://art-relief.blogspot.com/

Short Summary

I am an artist from India, currently living in Madison, WI. I have a PhD in Biology, but I have found my passion in art and I specialize in capturing some of the ephemeral art forms of India on permanent surfaces. I started painting textured artworks towards the end of 2011 and have been showing my works in and around Madison since February 2012. I have been showing in smaller venues like coffee shops and restaurants and participating in arts &
column2: crafts fairs. Along with these events and direct marketing I have sold more than 100 original paintings at an affordable price in the last couple of years. I have also used the proceeds from the sale of my paintings to support various community non-profits and also regularly donate artwork for fundraising events.

column1: For the next year, I want to take my artwork to more people and reach collectors through popular art festivals. Textured paintings that I create in the style of henna body art are unique and capture the colors and patterns that are part of everyday life in India. By going to professional art festivals, I will also be able to create awareness of ethnic art forms.

By contributing to my campaign, you will help me upgrade my booth set up which is much needed, even to qualify for these art festivals. (Photo under gallery on what the upgraded set up will look like)
What We Need
I am looking for $2000 minimum in donations to help with the following:
<ul>
• Flourish Mesh Display Panels - $700
• EZ UP Canopy 10'x10' tent with awning and sidewalls- $500
• Weight Bags, pack of four - $70
• Printed Name Banner - $50
• Spinner Rack for Notecards - $90
• Canvas Print Bins - $60
• Booth Fee for one Art Festival - $500

I am looking to participate in at least 20 art festivals in 2014 and on average the booth fees are about $400 for each show. Jury fees for each one is $50 on average. I will also need to triple my inventory of paintings before my first show and I will be saving up for these fees and cost of materials. Hence I need your support for helping me getting the required set up.

Any funds collected in excess of my asking amount will go towards jury fees, printing of promotional materials for the show and I can always use more paint. If I don't reach my funding goal, whatever money raised will go towards getting the tent and mesh panels.

What You Get

I cannot thank you enough for your support and in return for your contribution you will get one of the following: notecards, limited edition prints, a private henna party, custom crocheted scarfs (both for men and women), hand painted lazy Susan, hand painted plate  and original artworks on canvas! You also have the option of just contributing without choosing any perks or send your perk as a gift to someone. Samples of perks are posted in the Gallery.
The Impact

Your contribution in helping me go pro will be valuable in making my art visible to hundreds of thousands of people. For example, Madison's Art Fair on the Square attract 100,000 visitors over the weekend compared to about 3000 people for the neighborhood art and craft markets. Making it to juried art festivals will also help me take the next step in my art career by getting into galleries.
Other Ways You Can Help

I know that times are tough and if you just can’t contribute doesn’t mean you can’t help. Sharing this campaign on facebook, twitter, google +, talking about it to friends, and even an email or ten can go a long way towards helping me achieve my goal.
Thank You,
Bala

I came up to ideal of calling it EXCESSIVE VOYEURISM!  I invited fellow artist from Eatenbyducks blog to participate, also posted open call for collaborations in my website and my Facebook page, and also I have written to other interesting artist I know, from Lithuania as well. Since artists donated their artworks for free - I only need money for my zine publishing. All sponsors and businesses donated 20 USD or more will get a free copy! If I don't meet this projected goal  - my own money will be used to fill in the difference (since I don't have much...I don't want to sell my kidney!)

<h1 style=""font-family: georgia
OVERBURDEN - a two-channel video installation
West Virginia and witnessed the mining practice called Mountaintop
Removal. While
there, I spoke with residents who have lived in the mountains their
whole lives,
as have their ancestors. They told me how the coal companies have
systematically, and many times illegally,
taken their lands and turned them into barren fields where nothing
grows. There is no potable water in the coalfields, so if it can be
afforded, city water
is brought up in barrels or if not, the residents drink water that is
tainted
with mercury and arsenic among other toxins from coal processing and
mine
drainage. There are extremely high rates of birth defects and cancer in
Appalachia
column2: numbers the coal companies refute and have even insinuated

column1: are due
to inbreeding. Many residents feel that as the mountains are destroyed
around them and their requests for help from their elected officials are ignored or demeaned that their very sense of identity is being lost.
people I
spoke to feel helpless to stand up against King Coal and a corrupt state
government. Others are fighting as hard as they possibly can. Some stage
tree
sit-ins at the mine sites, others speak out in Washington. What I witnessed
in West Virginia made it difficult for me to believe that I was
still in a first world country. Most residents of West Virgina
are not against coal mining completely. In fact many of them are or were miners and
come from mining families. What they want is at minimum a return to safe
underground mining and the jobs it provides and a sustainable future.
response to last summerâ€™s experiences in Appalachia. The work will be a
dual-channel video installation comprised of footage of active and abandoned
mines from the ground and from the air juxtaposed with video portraits of
activists, local residents, miners and coal company officials. These images
reflect the conflicting realities of life in West Virginia: the
lushness of the landscape and the desolation of the mines. My goal is to create
a work that presents no single agenda other than exposing the complex issues
surrounding energy production in the United States.
requires tremendous focus and resources to complete. Your donations will help offset the travel expenses (airfare, hotel and car rental) necessary to complete the project.

<font size=""3"" style=""font-family: georgia
column2: >Deb Travis (Additional Photography/Driver) and I will make two trips this spring and summer to West Virginia for shoots

column1: and to
meet with activists, miners and residents. Our travels will begin in
Charleston, WV and we will work our way south along along the Coal River
to Beckley, WV making stops to visit mine sites and meet with folks
along the way.</font><font size=""3"" style=""font-family: georgia
column2: > In addition, Kate Freer (Assistant Camera) will join us on one leg of the trip to shoot aerial footage.</font>

drainage. There are extremely high rates of birth defects and cancer in
Appalachia
column2: numbers the coal companies refute and have even insinuated

column1: are due
to inbreeding. Many residents feel that as the mountains are destroyed
around them and their requests for help from their elected officials are ignored or demeaned that their very sense of identity is being lost.
Some
people I
spoke to feel helpless to stand up against King Coal and a corrupt state
government. Others are fighting as hard as they possibly can. Some stage
tree
sit-ins at the mine sites, others speak out in Washington. What I witnessed
in West Virginia made it difficult for me to believe that I was
still in a first world country. Most residents of West Virgina
are not against coal mining completely. In fact many of them are or were miners and
come from mining families. What they want is at minimum a return to safe
underground mining and the jobs it provides and a sustainable future.
Overburden is my
response to last summerâ€™s experiences in Appalachia. The work will be a
dual-channel video installation comprised of footage of active and abandoned
mines from the ground and from the air juxtaposed with video portraits of
activists, local residents, miners and coal company officials. These images
reflect the conflicting realities of life in West Virginia: the
lushness of the landscape and the desolation of the mines. My goal is to create
a work that presents no single agenda other than exposing the complex issues
surrounding energy production in the United States.
How your donation will help
This project
requires tremendous focus and resources to complete. Your donations will help offset the travel expenses (airfare, hotel and car rental) necessary to complete the project.
Deb Travis (Additional Photography/Driver) and I will make two trips this spring and summer to West Virginia for shoots
and to
meet with activists, miners and residents. Our travels will begin in
Charleston, WV and we will work our way south along along the Coal River
to Beckley, WV making stops to visit mine sites and meet with folks
along the way. In addition, Kate Freer (Assistant Camera) will join us on one leg of the trip to shoot aerial footage.
The Impact
This project is a departure from my previous work in its subject matter and breadth. It is also extremely expensive to create. Your support is invaluable to the process.
Other ways you can help
Please pass this campaign along to anyone who
might be interested. You can also help by posting a link to the campaign on Facebook or Twitter.
Thank you for your support!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

column1: A collective of guests artists and curators who explore the role of feminism in the art world and a platform for exhibitions, events, performances and discussion panels. Our first exhibition in September 2014 comprised of 3 curators and 21 artists demonstrating a great response on the artistic scene in NYC. Milk and Night is a new dynamic hub for a vibrant dialogue in intergenerational and intersectional feminisms. Its title comes from the poetical written words by philosopher Helene Cixous : “Eternity, it is the voice of milk mingled with night...my text is written in white and black, in milk and night”. It carries the dual aspect of life, as in body-spirit, as in light-dark, as in men-women, as in yin yang.
Milk and Night has established residence at Gallery Sensei in the Lower East Side NYC for the next 2 years.  A program of events and exhibition will be developed throughout 2014- 2016.

Milk and Nightʼs highly important mission is dedicated to substantiate the visibility of feminisms amongst the most prestigious art fairs. When the Art World is actively questioning its gender equalitarian status, we think it is important to be present and marketable. This is where you come in.
column5: >Milk and Night will be representing feminists artists in Basel Miami at Select Art Fair. As this is a unique project when no commercial galleries or booth on the entire map fair offers market visibility for feminists artists. We are calling private fundings to make a difference.

column1:
HOW WILL YOUR DONATIONS BE REWARDED?

Where will your donations go?

Booth rental Fee at Select Art Fair ($3,000)• 2 Flight Tickets, director+assistant ($1,200) • Hotel in Miami for 8 nights ($1,000) • General art fair week expenses ($1,000) • Promotion materials (business cards-flyers-banners-prints production) ($900) 

• VIABILITY FOR THE PROJECT is $7,000

What is Select Art Fair?

SELECT is a contemporary art fair that features emerging and mid-career artists showcasing cutting-edge art. SELECT 2014 will feature over 50 galleries from around the globe and is presently curated by Tim Goossens (MoMA PS1). SELECT will be held in a 40,000 square foot tent structure on Collins Avenue between 72nd and 73rd street, located just three blocks from NADA along the sands of beautiful North Beach. The location has perks such as, beach front views, an attached parking lot, and an amphitheater for music and arts programming.

$1,000 donation or more : a choice of one (1) original select work of art of equal value by Gallery Sensei represented artists Hector Leonardi, Karl Mann, Derek des Islets and Mari Keeler. http://gallerysensei.com/
$500 donation or more : a choice of five (5) limited edition prints by four of the following Milk and Night artists. Ange (ThreeAsfour) -

","SELECT Art Fair welcomes Milk and Night to Miami this year with special announcement about our program of artworks and performances. We ask for your support to help with our production costs. Our artists have made unique editions of their work available as thanks for your donations. Original works from Gallery SENSEI artists also available. Scroll down to see rewards.We have only three days left and would appreciate your participation in this important feminist platform.
WHAT IS MILK AND NIGHT?

A collective of guests artists and curators who explore the role of feminism in the art world and a platform for exhibitions, events, performances and discussion panels. Our first exhibition in September 2014 comprised of 3 curators and 21 artists demonstrating a great response on the artistic scene in NYC. Milk and Night is a new dynamic hub for a vibrant dialogue in intergenerational and intersectional feminisms. Its title comes from the poetical written words by philosopher Helene Cixous : “Eternity, it is the voice of milk mingled with night...my text is written in white and black, in milk and night”. It carries the dual aspect of life, as in body-spirit, as in light-dark, as in men-women, as in yin yang.
Milk and Night has established residence at Gallery Sensei in the Lower East Side NYC for the next 2 years.  A program of events and exhibition will be developed throughout 2014- 2016.

Milk and Nightʼs highly important mission is dedicated to substantiate the visibility of feminisms amongst the most prestigious art fairs. When the Art World is actively questioning its gender equalitarian status, we think it is important to be present and marketable. This is where you come in. Milk and Night will be representing feminists artists in Basel Miami at Select Art Fair. As this is a unique project when no commercial galleries or booth on the entire map fair offers market visibility for feminists artists. We are calling private fundings to make a difference.
http://gallerysensei.com/Milk-and-Night
Opening night at Gallery Sensei September 5th, 2014
WHO IS SUPPORTING MILK AND NIGHT?

• Gallery SENSEI is a New York based gallery established by Joseph Latimore (Gavin Brown Gallery/Passerby). Its new home was launched January 2014 in the heart of the New York contemporary emerging galleries in Chinatown. Gallery SENSEI has been selected as one of 50 exhibiting galleries at SELECT MIAMI. Milk and Night will be featured on its SELECT fair booth, with its own private 100 square feet space. Milk and Night will be covered by the galleryʼs insurance and shipping costs and will remain under the banner of the galleryʼs entity as an independent residency project. Gallery Sensei will not take a percentage of Milk and Night sales. Sales will be divided into %50 to the artists, %50 to Milk and Night project.
• The PRESS

Our curators : Anne Sherwood Pundyk, Katie Cercone, Coco Dolle

Our portfolio of artists : Ange, Anne Sherwood Pundyk, Antonia Perez, Asha Cherian, Betty Tompkins, Bianca Casady, Coco Dolle, Elisa Garcia de la Huerta, India Salvor Menuez, Jemima Kirke, JK5, Katie Cercone, Kara Rooney, Kembra Pfahler, Leah Aron, Lola Montes Schnabel, Marcia Jones, Mariko Passion, Michael Tousana, Mika and Claire, Nancy Azara, Virginija Babusyte-Venckuniene.

• The founding Director of Milk and Night : Coco Dolle, curator, producer, visual and performance artist based in NYC. Her work has been exhibited at Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, Mary Ryan Gallery, Berkeley Art Museum, Fountain Art Fair. She performed extensively in artistic events such as Deitch Project's Art Parades, the Whitney Museum, Performa13. Her work features in numerous private collections. For more infos http://www.cocodolle.com/ . Read her personal story on feminism : http://www.brooklynrail.org/2014/09/criticspage/my-french-american-potluck
